HEADLINE: A Dismal Outlook for Growth

BYLINE: ANNIE LOWREY


HIGHLIGHT: Technological advances raised American living standards through most of the 20th century, but those days may be over, according to a new paper. 

 BODY:
They don't call it the dismal science for nothing.
In a new paper, the Northwestern economist Robert J. Gordon argues that the United States should get ready for an extended period of slowing growth, with economic expansion getting ever more sluggish and the bottom 99 percent getting the short end of the (ever-slower-growing) stick.
"A provocative 'exercise in subtraction' suggests that future growth in consumption per capita for the bottom 99 percent of the income distribution could fall below 0.5 percent per year for an extended period of decades," he writes.
To put that in context, American households' real consumption expanded by about 3 percent a year before the recession hit and has been growing about 2 percent a year during the recovery, according to statistics from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
Mr. Gordon's paper joins a growing economic literature that seeks and fails to find new sources of bang-up growth. (See Tyler Cowen's wonderful "The Great Stagnation" for more on that.) 
In the past, the United States economy grew quickly and its citizens got richer, in no small part because of advances made in three consecutive industrial revolutions: steam engines and railroads first; electricity, indoor plumbing and the combustion engine second; and the computing revolution third.
But the productivity and income gains begot by that third revolution have not been as impressive as the productivity and income gains from the first and second, he writes. Moreover, the United States is facing a number of headwinds. We've gotten most of the gains from the "demographic dividend." Inequality is rising. Higher education is getting more costly, and student performance waning. We have high levels of government and household debt. And we have taxes and regulations stifling innovation and businesses.
That leads Mr. Gordon to question the notion that growth is a "continuous process that will persist forever." We might not stop growing. But he argues we will stall out.
"Doubling the standard of living took five centuries between 1300 and 1800. Doubling accelerated to one century between 1800 and 1900. Doubling peaked at a mere 28 years between 1929 and 1957 and 31 years between 1957 and 1988," he writes. "But then doubling is predicted to slow back to a century again between 2007 and 2100."
Of course, there could be revolutionary new sources of growth: from the singularity, maybe, or a new renewable energy source. An article about "The Next Great Growth Cycle" also has some good pushback on the doom-and-gloom economic narrative.

HEADLINE: Is Economic Growth Going Down The Drain?

BYLINE: PAUL KRUGMAN


HIGHLIGHT: Plumbing versus Facebook. 

 BODY:
FT Alphaville has an ungated version of Robert Gordon's latest pessimistic paper on prospects for long-run economic growth (pdf). It's not the first time Gordon has written on this subject, although I believe this is his first definitive statement that the IT revolution has been a big disappointment.
I have mixed feelings on that one; I see his point, but wonder whether there may be a lot more yet to come. But really, the point of such papers is to make you think differently. And I was very struck by Gordon's big example: the relative importance of fancy electronics (which he considers part of the Third Industrial Revolution) as compared with indoor plumbing (part of the second):
 A thought experiment helps to illustrate the fundamental importance of the inventions of IR #2 compared to the subset of IR #3 inventions that have occurred since 2002. You are required to make a choice between option A and option B. With option A you are allowed to keep 2002 electronic technology, including your Windows 98 laptop accessing Amazon, and you can keep running water and indoor toilets; but you can't use anything invented since 2002.
 Option B is that you get everything invented in the past decade right up to Facebook, Twitter, and the iPad, but you have to give up running water and indoor toilets. You have to haul the water into your dwelling and carry out the waste. Even at 3am on a rainy night, your only toilet option is a wet and perhaps muddy walk to the outhouse. Which option do you choose?
Indeed. If you visit one of my favorite places, the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, what's really striking about the early 1860s incarnations of the building was the lack of plumbing: outhouses outside, and water from a nearby well (with exactly the high infant mortality you'd expect as a result). By the 1930s the apartments were still grim -- I described them to my parents, and they said "We grew up in that apartment!" -- but they did have plumbing. And I'd say that nothing in these past 80 year matches that.

HEADLINE: Why Hayek Isn't Paul Ryan's Guru

BYLINE: BRUCE BARTLETT


HIGHLIGHT: Paul D. Ryan likes to cite the economist Friedrich von Hayek as an influence, but Hayek supported national health care and questioned Ronald Reagan's policies, an economist writes. 

 BODY:
Because the Republican presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, remains an enigma to almost everyone, those seeking insight into his core philosophy have focused on his choice of Representative Paul D. Ryan, who has been much more forthcoming about his intellectual influences, as his running mate.
Mr. Ryan has credited a variety of people, from the Representative Jack Kemp to the libertarian novelist Ayn Rand, for his thinking. An article in this week's New York Times Magazine credits another: the economist Friedrich von Hayek. Mr. Ryan mentions Hayek among his influences in the introduction to his Roadmap for America's Future, which embodies his plan to slash the size of government.
Hayek has long been popular among conservatives mainly because of one book, "The Road to Serfdom," published by the University of Chicago Press in 1944. Although written for a British audience - the Austrian-born Hayek was teaching at the London School of Economics when he wrote it - the book found its greatest success in the United States.

The New York Times had a great deal to do with the success of "The Road to Serfdom." Its introduction was written by John Chamberlain, who had been The Times's principal book reviewer in the 1930s. The Times's book review was written by one of its editorial writers, Henry Hazlitt, who was effusive in his praise not only for the book's substance but for its elegant style as well. It was featured on Page 1 of The Book Review on Sept. 24, 1944.
According to Hayek's biographer, Alan Ebenstein, The Times's review was the major reason that "The Road to Serfdom" became a best seller. Indeed, its influence continues, aided by recommendations from Representative Ron Paul, Republican of Texas, and the radio host Glenn Beck to members of the Tea Party movement.
Hayek's basic thesis is that socialism inevitably transforms into totalitarianism. A key reason is that socialism cannot work economically, he believed. During the 1930s, Hayek was in the forefront of the socialist calculation debate, in which he, Ludwig von Mises and other economists proved that pure socialism had to fail because it lacked a true price system to guide efficient production and distribution.
The inevitable failure of socialism, Hayek thought, would eventually require authoritarian methods to try to make it work, as was the case in the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany. At the time he wrote his book, Britain, France and other European countries were adopting explicitly socialist policies, like state ownership of major businesses and industries.
Although there has never been much support for European-style socialism in America, World War II and the New Deal led to a great expansion of government. In 1944, it looked as if the United States were traveling rapidly in the same direction as Europe, and Hayek's thesis was not implausible, given recent history.
The big problem for that those who continue to cite "The Road to Serfdom" as a guide is that they must essentially ignore everything that happened after 1944. Communism's high-water mark occurred a few years later, and before long it became obvious that communism was not a path to prosperity. Nor has anything remotely like Nazism ever resurfaced.
By the 1970s, few reputable economists really thought that socialism was a good idea. Ironically, one of them was Gunnar Myrdal, with whom Hayek shared the 1974 Nobel in economic science.
In 1979, the conservative Margaret Thatcher, whom Hayek greatly admired, became prime minister of Britain and quickly began selling the state enterprises that had been acquired after the war. "Privatization" became a worldwide phenomenon, and the number of state-owned enterprises fell. Communism collapsed in 1989, and the Soviet Union dissolved in 1991.
Thus postwar history is exactly the opposite of what Hayek predicted. Liberalism did not beget socialism, which did not beget totalitarianism.
Another problem for conservatives like Mr. Ryan is that Hayek would have been likely to oppose many of their pet ideas, like abolishing Medicare. In "The Road to Serfdom," Hayek explicitly endorsed social insurance:
Nor is there any reason why the state should not assist the individuals in providing for those common hazards of life against which, because of their uncertainty, few individuals can make adequate provision. Where, as in the case of sickness and accident, neither the desire to avoid such calamities nor the efforts to overcome their consequences are as a rule weakened by the provision of assistance - where, in short, we deal with genuinely insurable risks - the case for the state's helping to organize a comprehensive system of social insurance is very strong.
In "The Road to Serfdom," Hayek also endorsed state aid to victims of floods and earthquakes, government policies to regulate working hours and to control poisonous substances. In other writings and interviews, he endorsed antitrust laws, a minimum wage and even the Tennessee Valley Authority, long a right-wing bête noire. In a 1982 interview with The New York Times, Hayek was even skeptical of Ronald Reagan's economic plan, calling it "a very risky thing to do."
Moreover, Hayek was not doctrinaire about the importance of political freedom. In a 1979 interview with The Times, he defended the Chilean regime of Augusto Pinochet, which combined political repression with free-market economics, calling the results "absolutely fantastic." Asked whether this view was inconsistent with his philosophy, Hayek replied, "You can have economic freedom without political freedom, but you cannot have political freedom without economic freedom."
For such transgressions, some on the right have long viewed Hayek as a dubious ally. For example, the libertarian economist Walter Block wrote a detailed attack on Hayek in 1996 for being at best a lukewarm defender of the free market.
I suspect that in his heart, Representative Ryan is more attracted to the dogmatism of Rand than the complex, nuanced philosophy of Hayek, who told the Cornell political scientist Theodore Lowi that Rand angrily called him "a compromiser" on the only occasion they met.

HEADLINE: CBS News Poll Finds Presidential Candidates Essentially Tied

BYLINE: MARJORIE CONNELLY


HIGHLIGHT: In the poll, President Obama was backed by 46 percent of registered voters, and Mitt Romney was preferred by 45 percent. 

 BODY:
As the Republicans began to gather in Tampa, Fla., for their convention this week, the latest CBS News poll shows the race between President Obama and Mitt Romney essentially tied. 
Mr. Obama is backed by 46 percent of registered voters, and Mr. Romney, the presumptive Republican nominee, is preferred by 45 percent. Ninety percent of Republicans support Mr. Romney; just about as many Democrats want to see Mr. Obama re-elected. Independents are evenly divided - 40 percent for Mr. Obama and 41 percent for Mr. Romney. 
As is often the case, women are more inclined to support the Democratic candidate, preferring Mr. Obama by 10 percentage points. Men are 9 points more likely to back Mr. Romney. 
Voters are closely divided in their overall attitudes about the candidates. Mr. Obama is viewed favorably by 41 percent and unfavorably by 44 percent. Twelve percent are undecided. 
Similarly, 31 percent regard Mr. Romney in a positive light, and 36 percent have a negative opinion. But more voters are unable to give an opinion about Mr. Romney, a former governor of Massachusetts: 17 percent said they were undecided, and 15 percent said they were too unfamiliar with Mr. Romney to offer any judgment. 
Mr. Obama is seen as understanding the voters' needs and problems, but only about a third thinks he has a clear plan for creating jobs. Fewer voters see Mr. Romney as a candidate that empathizes with their troubles, but they are evenly divided on whether he has a strategy for dealing with unemployment. 
The nationwide poll was conducted Aug. 22 to 26 using landlines and cellphones with 1,218 adults of whom 1,051 said they are registered to vote. The margin of sampling error for voters is plus or minus 3 percentage points.

HEADLINE: Filling the Empty Suit

BYLINE: BILL KELLER


HIGHLIGHT: The GOP's convention managers would be wise to emphasize Romney's leadership strengths over his likeability - a task that's ultimately up to the candidate himself. 

 BODY:
TAMPA, Fla.
I'm a convention curmudgeon. I've been a fitful convention-goer since the 1976 Republican show in New York. They are tedious, scripted events matched and surpassed in their shallowness by the ceaseless chorus of commentary supplied by my tribe. What we do here is not journalism, it is theater criticism of an especially pedestrian order. The real reporters in Tampa would rather be covering Isaac.
And yet this particular piece of theater has a simple and important purpose, in this election possibly a decisive purpose. 
It is not to "frame the debate" - we know what the stakes are, and there will be actual debates in which we can hope the candidates highlight their starkly different views of what government is for. 
It is certainly not to flesh out the Romney agenda. The candidate has not so far deigned to put meat on the rhetorical bones of his intentions. (An editorial in The Economist magazine described his 59-point "Romney Program for Economic Recovery, Growth and Jobs" as "Fifty Shades of Grey" without the sex.) He has withheld the details for the same reason he has withheld his tax returns - they would provide ammunition for his critics. Let's hope he doesn't get away with this until November, but the convention will not be the place we learn what tax loopholes he would close or what government programs he would shred. 
The purpose of the convention is not mainly to cast doubt on the record of President Obama. The doubt is already plentiful, in both parties. Obama's record has been disappointing. Not nearly as disappointing as the speakers in Tampa will claim, and much of the blame is fairly laid at the feet of obstructionist Republicans. But when you compare the promise of Obama's inauguration, those lofty expectations, with the large majorities who feel now the country is stuck on the wrong track, that is a simple, undeniable metric of disappointment. Tell us something we don't know.
No, the purpose of the convention is to fill the empty suit that is Mitt Romney with enough flesh and blood and spine that he becomes a more credible alternative to the disappointing incumbent.

The choreographers in Tampa seem to have decided that this means "humanizing" Romney - highlighting a sympathetic back story, an adoring family, a narrative of faith, a warmer side. Maybe. But even before Ann Romney's turn as the ultimate humanizer, this makeover has the feeling of Romney's handlers (and Fox News) trying too hard. Mitt Romney is not sentimental, he is not an empathizer, he is not fun, and no amount of homey anecdotes and loving testimonials will make him - to use the adjective of the week - "likeable." 
Portraying Mitt Romney as a guy you would invite to your kid's bar mitzvah is not credible. And in any case it's not enough. What voters are looking for, I think, is more ineffable. They are looking a combination of moral compass and strength of character. They want to be convinced that he gets them (which is not the same as being one of them), that when the hard choices come at him he will be governed by the right mix of decency and sturdiness, that he can detect the wisdom in the crosswinds of pressure, that they trust his judgment.
If Romney can pull that off, he will leave Tampa ahead in the polls, flush with cash, having shaken off the negatives the Democrats have blown their war chest flinging at him. It will not be over, but it will be his to lose.
If the convention managers are smart, they will worry less about his warmer side and lay before us his firmer side: the details of how he has been steady in the face of pressure, stories of how he has led rather than been led. But no amount of stagecraft alone can fill the empty suit. It has to come from the man himself, organically. And - as the campaign so far has demonstrated - it is very hard to fake.

        
Boomers and Entitlements: The Backlash

HEADLINE: Is Ron Paul Winning the Future?

BYLINE: ROSS DOUTHAT


HIGHLIGHT: Or do his gains within the G.O.P. reflect partisan incentives rather than principled shifts? 

 BODY:
With no actual convention to cover here in Tampa these last two days, the press has gravitated toward what you might call para-convention events: Newt Gingrich's week-long "Newt University" tutorial in conservative ideas, for instance, and Ron Paul's "We Are the Future" rally for his army of supporters, held Sunday at the University of South Florida. About Gingrich, at this point, there is little of interest to be said, but the boasting title of Paul's rally has at least some claim to be the truth, given how well the libertarian congressman performed with younger voters in the primary season. Writing for the American Conservative, Jim Antle makes a plausible case that Paul has moved the Republican Party in his direction, and might move it further still: From the party-wide enthusiasm for critiques of the Federal Reserve to the reappearance of "bona-fide noninterventionists" in Republican House contests to the emergence of Kentucky Senator Rand Paul as a more mainstream advocate for his father's ideas, Antle writes, "the rapid progress" of Paulism "in a short period of time is undeniable."
Antle also allows, however, that "Mitt Romney is about as far from Ron Paul as a Republican presidential nominee can be," and this cautionary notes raises the deeper question of whether the Paul-ward shifts that he's describing would survive a Romney presidency. Both on the front where I'm most sympathetic to Paul's libertarian/paleoconservative cocktail (his skepticism about the use of military force abroad) and the front where I'm most skeptical (his goldbuggery and inflation paranoia), the gains he's made over the last few years probably owe as much to partisan polarization as to deep ideological transformation. In the age of Obama, opposing the Libyan War and railing against a potential QE3 is a low-cost way for Republican politicians to draw contrasts with a Democratic president's policies and interests. The real test will come when it's a Republican president contemplating sending troops to Syria or when it's a Republican economy that's being goosed by the Fed's monetary policy. I'm fairly confident that Rand Paul will raise his voice in criticism in those cases; I'm much less confident that there will be any kind of Paulista groundswell rising with him.
The post-2012 challenge for Paul's future-looking followers, then, isn't building a movement that will outlast the man himself. It's building a movement that will outlast the current political moment, and endure even when the incentives of partisanship cut a different way.

HEADLINE: Amid a Defense Budget Fight, Military Families Plan for the Worst

BYLINE: AMY BUSHATZ


HIGHLIGHT: Though used to dislocation and stress, some military families are deeply anxious about the "what-ifs" of coming defense budget cuts. 

 BODY:
My husband doesn't whisper. So when he leaned into me before his 2009 deployment and whispered that soldiers - many soldiers - were going to die where they were going in Afghanistan, I listened. Yet I am the kind of practical woman who could hear his fear and chalk it up to predeployment jitters.
My husband was right about that deployment. In four months, 20 members of our unit, the 1-17 Infantry Battalion, Fifth Brigade, Second Infantry Division, out of Joint Base Lewis-McChord, Wash, died. I spent every other Wednesday at a military memorial sitting behind friends whose husbands were now among the fallen. 
Events like that leave scars. Like so many of my fellow military spouses, I no longer believe that every story ends with "happily ever after." I no longer believe that things always turn out for the best. I no longer think that threats are always empty.
Which is why when elected officials and pundits rant and rave about the Congressional plan to ax $460 billion from America's defense budget over the next 10 years, I feel uneasy. That surprises me. After working as a reporter on Capitol Hill, I know more than my fair share about the process of putting together a federal budget. I know that politicians often speak in hyperbole. 
But I also empathize with military families who are deeply anxious about the "what-ifs" of sequestration - the technical term for the automatic cuts written into law last year that require a sweeping, 10 percent cut to most federal programs, including defense.
Military families rely on programs financed by the Defense Department to make the challenges of military life just a little more bearable. Things like subsidized child care, easy access to a grocery store and emotional health therapy keep us sane in the face of intense stress.
Fiscal screaming matches in Washington are typically resolved without leaving the Defense Department or life as we know it in tatters. But the panic surrounding the debate is starting to drown out voices of reason. Listening to politicians make proclamations that the Pentagon spending cuts will "cause economic devastation that will follow you for decades," as Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, recently did, is becoming increasingly hard to ignore.
When it comes to what programs and subsidies might be cut, rumors run rampant, especially among those who don't fully understand how the complicated budget process works or, in some cases, fails. And those rumors are starting to take their toll.
"I heard they may take away our housing allowance," one Navy spouse recently told me, even though I know of no military or Congressional official who has officially floated a cut in housing allotments. "If they do that, we won't be able to afford to live near my husband."
Military spouses know from experience that sometimes the worst does actually happen. Before deployment, every military family is lectured by their leadership on the importance of having a plan just in case their service member is seriously injured or killed. Who will take care of his medical decisions? Where will he be buried? Who will receive the military death insurance money?
The fearmongering that has accompanied the discussion around sequestration has sent many into "plan for the worst" mode. So instead of giving deployment preparation or recovery the full attention it deserves, many of us are distracted by wondering whether budget cuts will leave our service members with inadequate weapons or body armor, our pocketbooks short on rent or our posts and bases without the support structures we rely on to make life just a little bit easier.
Is using the already strained emotions of military families as a pawn in what seems to be an ideological temper tantrum really fair or necessary?

HEADLINE: Five Questions for S.C. Gov. Nikki Haley

BYLINE: JEFF ZELENY


HIGHLIGHT: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina is not only attending her first Republican National Convention here this week, but she also was asked to deliver one of the event's marquee speeches. Here are five questions from an interview on Tuesday. 

 BODY:
TAMPA, Fla. - Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina is not only attending her first Republican National Convention here this week, but she also was asked to deliver one of the event's marquee speeches. Here are five questions from an interview on Tuesday. 
Q.
 What is one thing that you know about Mitt Romney that voters may not realize? 
A.
 I love the fact that in 2008, Governor Romney was a candidate that wanted to win. What are you seeing now is not a candidate that wants to win, but a leader who has spent the last four years saying, 'How would I have handled that situation? 
Q.
 A candidate who wanted to win, what do you mean? 
A.
 So many times candidates go in and they go through the talking points and they say what they think people want to hear. It's very different when you watch a candidate become a leader, when they've actually watched and say ok, 'If I was in that position, how would I have handled that? 
Now we are seeing a better candidate because he's not thinking about being a candidate, he's thinking about being a leader. He's thinking about being a president and he's showing all the signs of being a great one. 
Q.
 Does Mr. Romney need to become more likeable or improve his appeal to voters? 
A.
 We don't elect people because they look good in a picture or hold a baby well. We elect people because they have proven results. He has proven results. It's not about liking him. People don't care about liking who they elect. They care about electing someone who is going to work for them, that's going to fight for them, that's going to prove that they deserve to be there. That's what he needs to do this week. 
Q.
 Have some Republicans - like Representative Todd Akin of Missouri - contributed to the Democratic argument that Republicans are waging a 'war on women?' 
A.
 It's not serious, it's silly. Akin's comments were just insulting - it's embarrassing for him, but when you look at the party in general, for Democrats to imply that women are one-issue voters is insulting to me. It's demeaning to women. Women consider everything. They care about jobs and the economy. They are about health care and how it's going to affect families. They care about the debt that's been passed on to their children and they care if their debt is going to mean anything. I know pro-life women in the Democratic Party. I know pro-choice women in the Republican Party. 
Q.
 Can you share a highlight of your Tuesday night speech? 
A.
 "I'm going to talk about how the hardest part of my job as governor of South Carolina has been this administration."

HEADLINE: Selective Memory in Tampa

BYLINE: ANDREW ROSENTHAL


HIGHLIGHT: Today's convention speakers avoided mentioning George W. Bush. 

 BODY:
The Republican speakers at the first night of the party's convention in Tampa kept shouting that "it is time" or "about time" or "past time" that the United States had a president who appreciates small businesses, or hates red tape, or wants to get rid of regulations, or wants to cut taxes.
"Small business needs a leader who will not avoid dealing with difficult issues, a leader with experience to understand what it takes," said Jack Gilchrist, a small business owner from New Hampshire who was introduced by his state's Senator Kelly Ayotte, who is most famous for trying to repeal the burdensome regulation banning the torture of prisoners.
The speakers--who by the way seemed to give the exact same speech over and over again--were carrying on as if they'd been out of power for ages. But wasn't George W. Bush president for eight years before Barack Obama? In fact, weren't Republicans in the White House for all but 12 years between 1968 and Mr. Obama's election in 2008? 

Sure, conventions are an exercise in misdirection, in the airbrushing of history and in gauzy presentation. But it is striking the way the 2012 Republicans are ignoring Mr. Bush, who was president from 2001 until 2009 and was given the same sort of grossly overblown accolades at his two conventions that were showered on Mr. Romney tonight and will be showered on him for two days more. 
This gathering of Republicans is an exercise in selective memory, and it has to be. Otherwise they might have to grapple with the fact that Mr. Bush and his allies in Congress cut taxes, and presided over the disintegration of the Clinton-era budget surpluses. In the not-so-distant past we had a Republican president, a one-time businessman, who hated red tape, and under his watch the grossly under-regulated financial system collapsed, bringing on the Great Recession.

HEADLINE: Love, Not Politics?

BYLINE: ANDREW ROSENTHAL


HIGHLIGHT: The genius of Ann Romney's performance was the way she smiled so warmly as she slipped the knife into President Obama. 

 BODY:
If the purpose of the Republican National Convention was to convince Americans that someone named Romney has a soul, a heart and a rich character, then it succeeded tonight. Only the Romney's name is Ann, not Mitt.
The Republican nominee's wife gave a well written and professionally delivered speech that was full of warm talk about the special role and burden of women in American society, about falling in love with Mr. Romney, about their marriage and about her certainty that he will fix pretty much everything that's wrong with America.
(Although, when you think about it, which political wife would take that stage and declare her lack of certainty?) 
And, like many great political speeches, hers began with a declaration that "I want to talk to you tonight not about politics and not about party," and then went on to talk mostly about politics and party.
Like when Mrs. Romney spoke about "the working moms who love their jobs but would like to work just a little less to spend more time with the kids, but that's just out of the question with this economy."
Or when she said: "These last few years have been harder than they needed to be. It's all the little things -- that price at the pump you just can't believe, the grocery bills that just get bigger; all those things that used to be free, like school sports, are now one more bill to pay. It's all the little things that pile up to become big things. And the big things -- the good jobs, the chance at college, that home you want to buy, just get harder. Everything has become harder."
No politics there.
The genius of Mrs. Romney's diva performance was the way she smiled so warmly as she delicately slipped the knife into President Obama. This was no Sarah Palin, who was all teeth and no warmth.
"It amazes me to see [Mitt's] history of success actually being attacked. Are those really the values that made our country great? As a mom of five boys, do we want to raise our children to be afraid of success? Do we send our children out in the world with the advice, "Try to do okay?"
Mrs. Romney added: "And let's be honest, if the last four years had been more successful, do we really think there would be this attack on Mitt Romney's success?"
Cue the knowing smile, the small, sharing chuckle, and the little nods of recognition and waves as if she had just spotted a familiar face in the huge crowd.

HEADLINE: On Our Radar: Green Tuesday at the White House

HIGHLIGHT: Tuesday's environmental news.

On Tuesday it was environmental news day for the Obama administration.
First, the announcement that by 2025 cars and light trucks must meet the equivalent of a 54.5-miles-per-gallon standard, doubling the fleet's current fuel efficiency. [CBS News]

Two campers have died and 1,700 more who stayed at Yosemite National Park may have been exposed to the rodent-carried hantavirus. It can take as much as six weeks after infection for flulike symptoms to develop.The virus is fatal in 30 percent of all cases. [Associated Press]
The scientific journal Geophysical Research Letters and some sister publications have collected and put online allthe papers concerning the March 2011 Japanese earthquake and tsunami. [Geophysical Research Letters]

HEADLINE: Live Updates From the Republican National Convention

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: The Times will be providing updates and analysis from the Republican National Convention in Tampa. 

 BODY:
Mitt Romney's six-year quest for the Republican presidential nomination will culminate Tuesday afternoon when the 4,400 delegates gathered here officially make him their choice to reclaim the White House from President Obama and the Democrats. The roll call vote will be followed by an evening of speakers including Mr. Romney's wife Ann and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie.
The Times will be providing updates and analysis from Tampa on our live dashboard. You can also follow along on Twitter @thecaucus, or follow our list of Times journalists covering the convention.
11:39 P.M. | That's a Wrap
That's a wrap for the first full day the the Republican National Convention. Come back tomorrow for more live coverage.
- 
11:21 P.M. | The Blue Screen
It swirled. It moved. It faded in and out, turning brighter blue, then fading out, like a lava lamp. It made some viewers - if you believe Twitter - feel slightly nauseated.
What was it? 
The blue background behind many of the speakers at Mitt Romney's convention.
Not all of the speakers got the car-sickness-inducing treatment behind them. Ann Romney, for example, had a more static blue background while she spoke. Other speakers stood in front of a red backdrop.
But many of the speakers delivered their addresses while the the colors of the blue backdrop - a high-tech video wall - mushed back and forth. It quickly became a fixation on Twitter as viewers took note of the oddity.
"It was a bit twilight zonish, where someone is being brainwashed," one posted.
Another wrote: "OK, am I tripping on acid cuz that wavy moving blue screen behind Chris Christie sorta makes me feel like I am."
There is precedent for such backdrop issues. 
At the 2008 Republican National Convention, Senator John McCain accepted his nomination in front of a huge digital image of a school. But all that showed on the TV screen was the bright green of the schoolyard lawn behind him.
Aides for Mr. Romney had bragged about the high-tech stage, which cost more than $2.5 million to build. They had said they were especially proud of the many video screens behind the speakers, which could be programmed any way they wanted.
Asked on Tuesday night about the odd blue screen, one adviser simply wrote: "Everyone wants to be a program director."
- 
11:23 P.M. | Some Delegates Missing in Action During Speeches
Ann Romney and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey gave the two big speeches of the night. The convention floor was alternately hushed and uproarious. So what are you doing milling on the third-floor walkway outside the arena as though it were seventh-inning stretch in a ball game?
"I'm charging my phone," said Curtis Loftis, the South Carolina chairman of the Romney campaign, sitting near a wall plug. 
"I'm treasurer of the state," he added. "I have a lot of work to do tomorrow, and I'm an early riser."
"I have vertigo," said Melody Howard, an alternate delegate from Nevada. "I'm up in the U section. It is very, very difficult. I didn't want to leave with a lot of people, so I'm heading out early.''
"It's a good time to go shopping," said David Johnson, an alternate from the United States Virgin Islands, taking advantage of no lines at the gift shop, where he picked up a couple of Romney-Ryan drink cozies for his fishing boat. "When I came by earlier, this place was mobbed."
His guest, Jennifer Galloway, a lawyer in Tampa, was also shopping while Mr. Christie could be seen but not heard on a nearby television. She bought a red "I built my business" T-shirt and a Romney banner for her 9-year-old son. 
"I'm taping the speeches at home," she said.
"I don't know how the hell people can listen to one of these - every guy says the same thing," said Leo Gildersleeve, the husband of a Texas delegate, as he sat waiting for his wife, June. "They could run this whole convention in two days. I'm 83 years old. I've got to get to bed."
- 
11:08 P.M. | Is Ann Romney Channeling Michelle Obama?
Has Ann Romney learned a thing or two from Michelle Obama's playbook? In her smiling but forceful convention speech, Mrs. Romney showed off many classic political-spouse rhetorical moves: the fond recollection of her romance, the "you don't know my husband" response to his critics.
A few moments specifically recalled lines of Mrs. Obama's. Mrs. Romney vowed that her husband would not fail; Mrs. Obama has said countless times that her husband never let her down.
Mrs. Romney also painted a bleak portrait of the struggles that women are facing: late nights, elderly parents, emergency rooms. She spoke about how the burdens of a stalled economy often fall on women. "It's the moms who always have to work a little harder, to make everything right," she said. "You're the ones who always have to do a little more." 
"I'm not sure if men really understand this, but I don't think there's a woman in America who really expects her life to be easy," she said. "In our own ways, we all know better." 
"Everything has become harder," she said.
In 2007, Mrs. Obama said nearly all of those things, talking about how the deck often seemed stacked against working families, about how an invisible bar just seemed to be getting higher. But the first lady changed her approach considerably by mid-2008, making her speeches far more upbeat, in part because she was criticized in that last campaign for having a vision of America that was too dark, for what many critics called racially based resentment. "Mrs. Grievance," National Review called her. Will anyone notice that Mrs. Romney just made some of the same points?
- 
10:47 P.M. | Love or Respect 
The final message out of today's Republican convention was a little bit conflicted.
For Ann Romney, the wife of the Republican presidential nominee, the message boiled down to one word: "Love."
"I want to talk to you tonight about that one great thing that unites us, that one thing that brings us our greatest joy when times are good, and the deepest solace in our dark hours," she said in an address to the convention.
"Tonight I want to talk to you about love," she said.
But a few minutes later, Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, had a different take.
"Tonight," he said, "we choose respect over love."
- 
10:44 P.M. | Christie Asks Country to Face Hard Truths
Chris Christie, the sharp-tongued governor of New Jersey, on Tuesday extolled Mitt Romney as an exceptional leader willing to speak hard truths to a nation weary of President Obama's policies and ready to make a much-needed change.
"It's time to end this era of absentee leadership in the Oval Office and send real leaders to the White House," Mr. Christie said, according to prepared remarks. "America needs Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan, and we need them right now."
In delivering the keynote address at the Republican National Convention, Mr. Christie demonstrated his trademark bluntness - crediting his mother for teaching him how to speak "without much varnish" - but he did not lash out in personal ways at Mr. Obama, hardly mentioning the president by name.Read more ...
- 
10:29 P.M. | No Convention Watching Party for Obama
 FORT COLLINS, Colo. - President Obama checked into his hotel here early Tuesday evening after campaign rallies on two college campuses, with plans to read and get updates on Hurricane Isaac, an aide said - not to watch television coverage of the Republican convention.
 It is not hard to imagine why the president wouldn't want to watch the nonstop Obama-bashing in Tampa, Fla. But it meant that he would also miss the prime-time speech from Mitt Romney's wife Ann, much anticipated as a humanizing window into her husband. 
 One campaign adviser, who would not be identified critiquing the opposition's convention, said ahead of Mrs. Romney's appearance, "I'm sure she'll do well." But the aide suggested the Romney campaign had built expectations for her unrealistically high.
 And after hours of programming in which Republican women were ubiquitous - to try to counter what polls suggest is a bad image for their party among female voters - the Obama adviser suggested, "They seem to be under the belief that if you are surrounded by women, you understand women's issues. The two are not the same."
 Mr. Obama, seeking to energize young voters who could be crucial to his re-election hopes, spoke on Tuesday before a combined 19,000 people, mostly students, first at Iowa State University in Ames and then here at Colorado State University. On Wednesday morning - depending on Isaac's course - he will fly back east to a third rally at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville before returning to Washington.
- 
10:28 P.M. | About G.O.P. Support for the Individual Mandate 
Artur Davis, the former Democratic congressman from Alabama who fell short in his effort to win the Democratic nomination for governor a couple of years ago, used his speech on the floor of the Republican convention tonight to make the claim that Democrats had "rammed through" a health care law "without accepting a single Republican idea."
It is true that President Obama's health care law passed without Republican support. 
But the law's central, and most contested idea - of an individual mandate requiring people to buy coverage - was initially devised by conservatives and backed by Republicans, including Newt Gingrich, who saw it as a better alternative to a true government-run health system. 
It was also an idea that was seized on by a Republican who is very much on the minds of delegate in Tampa and viewers at home: the party's nominee, Mitt Romney.
- 
10:23 P.M. | This Convention, Brought to You by: 'You Built It'
Tuesday, the first full day of the Republican National Convention, brings a keynote by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, and a warm speech by Ann Romney meant to humanize her husband. But conventiongoers could be forgiven for thinking that the evening was brought to them by "You Did Build It."
Attacks on President Obama's "you didn't build that" comments last month in Virginia served as something of the unofficial motto of the night, infusing speakers' remarks, dotting hand-drawn signs, and echoing through the Tampa Bay Times Forum as they blared from overhead.
Between speeches, videos of Mr. Obama's remarks, followed by Mr. Romney's assertion that small-business owners deserve the sole credit for their success, played on huge screens hanging throughout the hall - little vignettes featuring real business owners meant to drive home what has become something of a rallying cry for Mr. Romney's campaign. 
When Gov. Mary Fallin of Oklahoma spoke, she, too, got in on the action, warning that if you're a voter who owns a small business, the president will tell you that you didn't build that.
"You think it's the I.R.S., the E.P.A., or the federal government?" she asked rhetorically (and incredulously).
When Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia took the stage, a large "We Built It" slogan appeared on the screen behind him, and he also offered up some "You did build that" red meat to the crowd: "You did make that happen," he said, to cheers. "You did build that in America."
And shortly after taking the stage, Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina couldn't resist a dig of her own. Recounting the story of her parents, who immigrated to the United States and founded their business out of their living room, she said, "So President Obama, don't tell me that my parents didn't build their business."
Even the R.N.C. pages got in on the fun, wildly waving hand-drawn red and blue signs that said - what else - "You Built It," as the politicians onstage echoed that very same message.
- 
10:16 P.M. | On the Floor, Away From the Speeches
Yes, there are important speakers on stage, but down on the floor, what the convention most resembles is a boisterous, arm-squeezing class reunion. 
Delegates and elected officials from across the country are greeting old friends and comrades in Republican arms, a quadrennial get-together.
"You've got people who've been to conventions for 20 years. It's good being together," said Representative J. Randy Forbes of Virginia, pumping the hand of a fellow member of Congress, who are allowed V.I.P. access to the floor even if they are not delegates.
Todd Staples, the Texas agriculture commissioner, chatted with his friend Gary Black, the agriculture commissioner of Georgia. "It's a shared vision for America that brings us together," Mr. Staples said.
Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, an also-ran candidate for the nomination during the hard-fought primary race, paid a surprise visit to the Texas delegation and embraced the state Republican chairman, Steve Munisteri, in a long bear hug. 
(Asked if had any regrets about not being the star of the week's show, Mr. Perry said: "I'm a team player. We've got one quarterback.")
Senator Roger Wicker of Mississippi posed for pictures and tightly gripped the arm of Christopher Shays, a former congressman from Connecticut, who lost a recent primary race to Linda McMahon, the wrestling entrepreneur, who Mr. Shays dismissed as "the billionaire."
"It's a Mississippi-Connecticut Yankee reunion," Mr. Shays said.
"This is a great man," Mr. Wicker, a member of the Senate Armed Services committee, said of Mr. Shays. "He came out to Iraq 20 times."
- 
10:13 P.M. | Waiting Backstage 
Mitt and Ann Romney are backstage, waiting for their big reveal. 
What to do? 
Well, watch TV, for one. (They are catching the convention proceedings on Fox News.) And make adoring, slightly nervous conversation with the cameramen standing around them. 
MR. ROMNEY: My better side is the side that Ann is on, cover me up and let her be seen. No one has ever suggested that I am the best side of this relationship let me tell you.
MR. ROMNEY: Break a leg, you'll do great.
MRS. ROMNEY: I am excited. I am not nervous.
MR ROMNEY: I am not nervous. She is going to be great.
Mr. Romney is planning to watch his wife speak from backstage. After she is done, he will join her out on the convention floor with their five sons.

10:09 P.M. | From the Morgue: Early Signs of Romney, 1964
- 
9:45 P.M. | A Show of Hands
Rick Santorum may have just handed down the most "hand"-laden convention speech in history.
The key line of his address: "I shook the hand of the American dream. And it has a strong grip."
But he did not stop there. He spoke of his daughter's hands. He spoke of shaking the gritty hands of restaurant workers. In all, there were about two dozen hands in the speech, according to Matt Viser of The Boston Globe, who reported his tally on Twitter.
Twitter immediately lighted up with references, admiring and mocking of the "Hand Speech." 
David Axelrod, an adviser to President Obama, quickly took a swipe at the former senator from Pennsylvania: "Santorum's speech: all hands, no Mitt!" he wrote.
- 
9:38 P.M. | Santorum Highlights Social Issues 
Rick Santorum injected conservative social issues into the nominating convention of his one-time rival, but did so before the prime-time lineup when television networks began paying attention.
Mr. Santorum and Mitt Romney engaged in a bitter fight for the nomination, with Mr. Santorum repeatedly deriding Mr. Romney's commitment to the social issues that he frequently espouses.
"Marriage is disappearing in places where government dependency is the highest," Mr. Santorum said. "Most single mothers do heroic work and an amazing job raising children. But the fact is, for America to succeed, we must stop the assault on marriage and the family in America today."
The two men made an uneasy peace with each other after Mr. Santorum's upstart campaign petered out in the face of Mr. Romney's well-financed effort. After bowing out, Mr. Santorum eventually endorsed Mr. Romney but has campaigned little on his behalf.
But unlike Representative Ron Paul of Texas, who remained a thorn in Mr. Romney's side and did not get a speaking slot, Mr. Santorum was offered the ability to speak at the convention.
He took that opportunity to reprise the themes of his presidential campaign, talking little about Mr. Romney and his qualifications for the White House and more about his own personal story.
Mr. Romney's campaign has sought to keep the convention on economic issues and jobs. But Mr. Santorum, as he did throughout 2011 and 2012, steered the political conversation back to abortion and other social issues.
- 
9:22 P.M. | Perry's Next Stand 
Texans - perhaps more than most - know when to hold 'em and know when to fold 'em. And on the floor of the Republican National Convention, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas wasn't ready to fold 'em just yet.
Greeting members of the cowboy hat-clad Texas delegation, Mr. Perry told reporters that he hadn't ruled out another run for president. And, in a mixed message of support for Mr. Romney, he said that his second shot at the White House might come in 2016 - when, potentially, Mr. Romney could be running for his second term.
"Oh, absolutely," Mr. Perry said, when asked if he'd ever run again. "It's a long time until 2016, and a lot of good things could happen."
Mr. Perry also said that his party's rough-and-tumble early nominating contests - "intramural scrimmages," as he called them - had helped prepare Mr. Romney for the general election.
"Whether they're in athletic events or whether they're in politics, it makes you strong," he said. "At the end of the day, it made Mitt stronger. It made him more prepared for the attacks that came from the Democrats. And he's going to be not only a better candidate, he's going to be a better president because of it."
Still, he couldn't resist getting in a final jab at his former opponent. Asked if he had any regrets about the sometimes vicious attacks he'd lobbed at Mr. Romney during the primaries, Mr. Perry chuckled and said, "Lord, no."
"We all have our shots that we take, and we give, and you know, I hope I gave as good as it took," he said.

9:14 P.M. | 'You Didn't Build That' in Context
 The recording of President Obama saying "you didn't build that" that is being played over the loudspeakers between speeches at the Republican convention has been selectively edited in a way that changes its meaning. 
 The recording being played in Tampa makes it sound as if the president had said: "Let me tell you something, if you've got a business - you didn't build that. Somebody else made that happen." Small-business owners are then quoted taking umbrage at his remarks, and explaining that they did build their businesses by dint of their hard work.
 But the unedited quote from the president tells a somewhat different story. Mr. Obama, at a campaign event last month at a fire station in Roanoke, Va., actually said: "Somebody invested in roads and bridges. If you've got a business - you didn't build that. Somebody else made that happen."

8:58 P.M. | Republicans Highlight Obama 'Switchers'
Republicans are eager to make the point that many of President Obama's supporters from 2008 are now going to vote for Mitt Romney.
They will demonstrate that with a video later Tuesday night called "Switchers," in which former supporters of Mr. Obama declare their intent to switch parties in the coming election.
"I caucused for him and went to the rallies and even donated to his campaign," one woman says in the video. "I'm not supporting Barack Obama this time because I just don't see things getting better."
The video was released to reporters earlier on Tuesday, but will be played on the big screens in the convention hall today just before the speech of Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina.

8:40 P.M. | Now It's Getting Personal
Political conventions are usually full of insults to leaders of the other party. But Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio took it to another level on Tuesday.
During his speech to the convention, Mr. Kasich recounted that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had boasted of being a good golfer. "I've played golf with Joe Biden," Mr. Kasich said, "and that's not true." Ouch!
Mr. Biden and Mr. Kasich played as a team against President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner last year and lost, which may explain Mr. Kasich's sour view of his erstwhile partner. But Mr. Biden might point to Golf Digest, which ranked the vice president 29th in its list of Washington's best golfers with a 6.3 handicap.

8:34 P.M. | Republican Speakers Press the 'We Built It' Message
Sher Valenzuela, a candidate for Delaware lieutenant governor, kicked off the Republican National Convention's theme du jour Tuesday evening with a full-throated defense of entrepreneurship and free enterprise against what she called President Obama's stifling regulations. The message: We Built It.
But the attack on Mr. Obama's "you didn't build that" gaffe stoked liberal fact-checkers, who said her company, First State Manufacturing, has received millions of dollars in federal loans and contracts. Indeed, a recent PowerPoint presentation, unearthed by the liberal group Media Matters for America, extolled businesses to reach out for government work. 
"Bidding on government contracts has never been easier, and it's getting easier all the time," the presentation read. "That's because government agencies are mandated to work with small businesses. That's why nearly all government agencies have special small-business programs to ensure the success of business owners just like you."
Since Mr. Obama uttered his "you didn't build it" line, defenders have said his Republican critics have been taking the line out of context. The president wasn't saying that entrepreneurs do not build their businesses; he was saying he did not build the roads, bridges and infrastructure that business uses - the line before the quote.
But the Romney campaign has hammered Mr. Obama with the line, so much that its counter - We Built It - has become a Republican mantra. In response, Democrats have sought out any government largess, no matter how insignificant, that has gone to businesses showcased by the Romney campaign. 
Still, the "you didn't build that" line has become one of the engines driving the Republicans at the moment, and it is showing no sign of running its course.

8:06 P.M. | Let's Call Room Service
Mitt Romney just won the Republican nomination for president of the United States. What's he doing to celebrate? Ordering room service.
Mr. Romney, who flew here to support his wife, Ann, spent the evening in a hotel suite. (Mrs. Romney will speak later Tuesday evening.) No word on what he ordered, but in addition to Mrs. Romney, he was joined by their son, Matt; his wife, Laurie; and two of their children, Mia, 8, and Nate, 4.
"They're having dinner, playing with the grandkids," Rich Gorka, a Romney spokesman, told reporters.

7:23 P.M. | Delegates Show State Pride in Fashion Choices
The tradition of wacky individualistic outfits at party conventions is a long one, so consider the effort it must take to enforce a delegation dress code.
Nonetheless, a number of state delegations are making their collective fashion statements. New Mexico's delegates are in turquoise polo shirts with the state's Zia sun logo. Many Michigan delegates have slipped on football jerseys emblazoned with "Ford" and "48," a tribute to former President Gerald R. Ford, who played center and linebacker for the University of Michigan before representing the state in Congress.
Oklahomans wore tasteful blue blazers for men and women, with a patch bearing the state seal. Mike Sanders, a delegate, said they had been voted best-dressed delegation by NPR twice, in 2012 and 2008.
Greg Treat, a delegate from Oklahoma City, said there was a debate this year about switching the color of the blazers to advance the state's claim to be the most Republican in the nation. "Several states claim to be the reddest state in the union,'' he said, "but because we had all 77 counties go red, we talked of having red blazers." Tasteful navy prevailed. 
West Virginians are making a political statement in black coal miner's hats. "We have a war on coal in this country," said Brian Long, a delegate, blaming President Obama and the Environmental Protection Agency for regulations making it harder to mine coal and run coal-fired power plants. "We're proud of our coal mines and coal miners," he said.
No surprise, the delegation making the loudest statement with its outfits is Texas. Almost all 155 members are in white straw cowboy hats and loose shirts patterned like the state flag, with a large lone star stamped over the right breast.
"Texans are proud, and we always wear our colors with pride," said Janis Holt, a delegate from Silsbee, Tex. 
And because the unofficial Texas motto might be "too much ain't enough," the delegation will retire Tuesday's uniform and pull out a second uniform for Wednesday night's activities.

7:17 P.M. | R.N.C. Uses Obama 2008 Theme Song
Delegates at the Republican National Convention are being serenaded with the song "Signed, Sealed, Delivered," a Stevie Wonder hit from 1970.
They are swaying and signing along as the convention's evening session gets under way.
But they might be a bit aghast if they realized that the song also has another provenance: it was the theme song for Barack Obama's 2008 campaign.
Mr. Obama's team played the song all the time on the trail, with Mr. Obama jogging out to a screaming crowd as the music crested.
And then, Mr. Wonder performed the song live - and in person - at, of all places, the 2008 Democratic National Convention.
Maybe Washington politicians can agree on something after all.

7:11 P.M. | Boehner to Serve the Red Meat 
In a night dedicated to sepia toned images of Mitt Romney, House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio dished the red meat to a Republican National Convention united in their dislike for President Obama.
Mr. Boehner mocked the president's record as well as his lofty slogans, past and present.
"His record is a shadow of his rhetoric," he said. "Yet he has the nerve to say that he's moving us forward, and the audacity to hope that we'll believe him."
And he used his own hard-scrabble background as the son of a bar owner who worked the place, to highlight the failures of Obama's presidency. He used the line "throw him out" to try to rally the crowd behind him.
"Believe me when I say I learned how to deal with every character who walked in the door," he said of his experience working in his dad's bar. "So let's say right now, a guy walked into our bar and said, 'the private sector is doing fine.' Well, do you know what we'd do? That's right: we'd throw him out. If a guy walked into our bar and said, 'if you've got a business, you didn't build that,' do you know what we'd do? Throw him out."
The speaker also threw his support behind Representative Paul Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, whom he has known from the first days of his political career but has clashed with in recent years.
"When I met Paul Ryan 22 years ago, he was a student at Miami of Ohio volunteering on my campaign. Soon, he will be our party's nominee for vice president of the United States," he will say. "Who says this isn't the greatest country on Earth?"

6:59 P.M. | Some Delegates Slow to Embrace Romney, Others Warm Up
Denise Nielsen, a Romney supporter and delegate from Ventura County, Calif., acknowledged that many Republicans have been slow to embrace Mr. Romney, attributing it to the many competing ideas and degrees of ideology in the party.
"But in modern-day America, you have to consider what is really feasible, what can we go with?" she said. "As far as being a person of integrity of faith and of someone who has certainly been honorable his entire life, I don't think anyone can assail him on those. People are feeling a lot more comfortable, and his personality is starting to come through."

6:30 P.M. | In Speech, Ann Romney Will Try to Humanize Mitt
Ann Romney will use her prime-time speech at the Republican National Convention to take some of the sheen off her husband's glossy image and try to humanize Mr. Romney with the very real struggles he has faced with dogged determination and inevitable success.
"I read somewhere that Mitt and I have a 'storybook marriage,'" she will say, according to speech excerpts released by the Romney campaign. "Well, in the storybooks I read, there were never long, long rainy winter afternoons in a house with five boys screaming at once. And those storybooks never seemed to have chapters on M.S. or breast cancer."
"A storybook marriage? No, not at all," Mrs. Romney will say. "What Mitt Romney and I have is a real marriage."
Many of the struggles her speech will discuss were not so much his, but hers and his father's. Mrs. Romney has multiple sclerosis and battled through breast cancer. The boot-strap section of the speech will belong to George Romney, Mitt's father who, she will remind viewers, "never graduated from college," and instead "became a carpenter" and slogged his way to head a car company, then become governor of Michigan.
But she will extol the determination of her husband.
"At every turn in his life, this man I met at a high school dance, has helped lift up others," she will say. "He did it with the Olympics, when many wanted to give up. This is the man who will wake up every day with the determination to solve the problems that others say can't be solved, to fix what others say is beyond repair. This is the man who will work harder than anyone so that we can work a little less hard."
Mrs. Romney will not dish red meat to the Republican faithful. From the beginning, she will make clear "I want to talk not about what divides us, but what holds us together an American family," love.
But the speech promises a rousing payoff.
"This man will not fail, this man will not let us down," she will promise. "This man will lift up America."

6:29 P.M. | Ryan Is Officially the Vice-Presidential Nominee
Steve King, the national committeeman for Wisconsin, placed Paul D. Ryan's name into consideration to be nominated to be the vice-presidential nominee. Republicans quickly agreed to Mr. Ryan's selection by acclamation, avoiding a long roll-call vote like the one for Mitt Romney. Mr. Ryan is scheduled to deliver his address to the convention on Wednesday night.

6:03 P.M. | Paul Supporters Criticize Process, Party and Rules
Earlier in the day, what was supposed to be a slow, orderly and only symbolic process erupted in anger, presenting a raucous scene that even the most seasoned delegates had not seen in some 30 years, an unexpected scene of disunity that, if for only a moment, harkened to the early days when conventions actually decided things.
Chanting "point of order" at the top of their lungs, the activists - almost all of them Ron Paul supporters - said that the party leadership had shut off their microphones and cut off their ability to raise an objection to the processes seating delegates and approving a new set of disputed rules pushed by the Romney campaign. None was louder than the Texas delegation, which drew extra attention to itself in the hall with cowboy hats and Texas-flag, button-down shirts.
The activists said they had built enough support in enough states to push a reversal of a party decision against seating several Ron Paul supporting delegates, and, more significantly, to submit a proposal rejecting the new rules pushed by the Romney campaign - which were approved in a thunderous voice vote - in a roll call vote.
"We got smushed,'' said Robert Tyree, a Nevada delegate.
A fellow Paul supporter from Nevada, Cindy Lake, fumed at being shut down, saying, "They said to us, you have no voice anymore, the Tea Party has no voice,'' adding, "This is a completely draconian disenfranchisement by the elite of the rank and file."
Activists on the floor here - dotted with the old fashioned placards marking each state delegation in red white and blue - said that earlier the rules committee deciding on the Romney rules proposal limited discussion, to reduce opposition. Mr. Romney's campaign had sought to tighten rules to ensure that a candidate who wins a state primary gets guaranteed support from the delegates they win.
Delegate apportionment varies by state, but under the current rules some states allow supposedly "bound" delegates to switch allegiance to another candidate on the convention floor - a system that helped persuade Mr. Paul, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich to stay in the nominating competition even as their losses in primaries and caucuses mounted.
On Tuesday night, a group of activist leaders and Romney officials struck a compromise, but some activists complained that it still gave party leaders in Washington power to change the rules again between national conventions.
That compromise won approval at a rules committee meeting in the afternoon, but Paul supporters said that was after limited discussion. And some of the activists said their leading champions - including the activist Morton Blackwell - were not able to attend the meeting due to transportation concerns, which some cast as suspicious.
"This is a return to smoke-filled rooms," said Steve Dickson, a delegate from Oklahoma.
Even after their cause - which included a desire by some to literally submit Mr. Paul's name for nomination - was quashed, Mr. Paul's fans screamed out their support every time a state announced some of its votes were going for Mr. Paul.
- 
5:43 P.M. | Delegates Officially Nominate Romney
Mitt Romney has officially become the Republican presidential nominee after New Jersey cast all of its ballots for him, giving him more than half of the delegates gathered in the hall.
The large screen on the platform in the convention hall read "Over the Top," as the crowd chanted "Mitt! Mitt! Mitt!" The many screens in the hall showed pictures of Mr. Romney and his family.
The moment was entirely expected after a divisive primary process in which Mr. Romney slowly but effectively pulled away from his rivals.
But the moment - unique to America's democracy - is nonetheless historic. Mr. Romney is now the leader of the Republican Party and its best hope to retake over leadership in Washington.
The crowd erupted immediately upon the announcement that Mr. Romney had clinched the nomination - an image of unity that Mr. Romney's campaign had long looked forward to.
Mr. Romney will formally accept the nomination on Thursday night.

5:35 P.M. | Tonight's Lineup
The schedule of speakers Tuesday evening is a parade of who's who's and who's that's, but there is a discernible logic to the lineup, which begins at 8 p.m. Each hour conforms to a theme, which must have made easier the jobs of schedulers. It begins with a procession of Republican governors, who, like gymnasts from the same team at the Olympics, seem stacked so that the top talent goes later.
Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire leads off, followed by Governors John R. Kasich of Ohio, Mary Fallin of Oklahoma, Bob McDonnell of Virginia and, finally, Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a party hero for his defiance of public employees' unions and survival of a recall election this year.
Diversity is the theme of the 9 p.m. hour. It starts with Gov. Brian Sandoval of Nevada, and continues with Sher Valenzuela, a candidate for lieutenant governor of Delaware; Ted Cruz, the Tea Party-supported Senate candidate in Texas who won an upset primary; Artur Davis, a former Alabama congressman who switched allegiance from the Democratic Party this year, and Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina.
The final hour at 10 p.m. leads off with Lucé Vela Fortuño, the first lady of Puerto Rico, where Mitt Romney won a crucial primary victory. Mrs. Fortuño will introduce Ann Romney for a much-anticipated speech. Mr. Romney is expected to make an appearance onstage with her. 
Finally, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will give the keynote speech.

5:32 P.M. | Iowa Goes to Paul
Rick Santorum and Mr. Romney pretty much tied in the Iowa caucuses, kicking off the Republican primary season, but don't tell that to Iowa's delegates at the Republican National Convention.
Iowa gave 22 of its votes to Ron Paul, the libertarian firebrand whose followers have been undaunted by his losses. Six went to Mr. Romney.
Iowa was one of several delegations taken over by Paul supporters. Another, Maine, split its vote: 14 to Mr. Romney, 10 to Mr. Paul. They have made noise on the floor, but are not about to deny Mr. Romney his nomination.

5:19 P.M. | State Roll Call Vote Under Way
The roll call of states has begun, with Alabama's representative declaring the state to be "on the move" and casting its votes for Mr. Romney.
The roll call vote will go on for more than an hour as the states vote, in alphabetical order, until Mr. Romney has received enough votes to officially claim the nomination.
Some presidential campaigns in the past have engineered the roll call so that a candidate's home state becomes the one to put them over the top and earn the nomination.
A top aide to Mr. Romney said that the campaign did not intend to do that tonight. Instead, the campaign plans to let the voting go in alphabetical order.
The adviser estimated that a state beginning with an "N" would probably put Mr. Romney over the top.

5:11 P.M. | 'Warmth' Is the Order of the Day
With the five Romney boys making the rounds and Ann taking center stage, the order of the Republican National Convention's first day of activities was to warm up Mitt Romney's image - to make delegates like him a lot, if not love him.
But talk to the delegates and Republican pooh-bahs that appeal has been aimed at. The predominate feeling is, warmth? Meh.
"I'm thrilled to have a businessman running for president, period," said Amanda Adkins, 37, chairwoman of the Kansas Republican Party, who went to the convention floor dressed as Dorothy from "The Wizard of Oz," beside another delegate who came as the Wicked Witch of the West and another as Glinda the Good Witch. The whole push to warm up the nominee is a "distraction from what really matters," she said.
That attitude came up again and again in interviews with delegates. Few said that Mr. Romney was a warm, likable figure. They just didn't much care.
"I don't care if he's warm and fuzzy," said Donna Hamilton, 74, a delegate from Washington State. "He's intelligent."
More professional politicians conceded there was good reason to burnish his image. Representative Brett Guthrie, Republican of Kentucky, said he spent time with the nominee for the first time a couple of weeks ago in Evansville, Ind. His wife turned to him in surprise to say Mr. Romney was a really nice guy.
"The warmth just doesn't come out" on television, Mr. Guthrie said. "If he could meet every single American, he'd win in a landslide."
"This is Mitt Romney's opportunity to show he has the vision to show where to lead America," said Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa, who readily conceded that the warmth thing wasn't shining through. "It's not enough to say the president has failed."

HEADLINE: In Keynote Speech, Christie Asks Country to Face Hard Truths

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR


HIGHLIGHT: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Tuesday extolled Mitt Romney as an exceptional leader, and as the right man to take the country in a different direction. 

 BODY:
TAMPA, Fla. -- Chris Christie, the sharp-tongued governor of New Jersey, on Tuesday extolled Mitt Romney as an exceptional leader willing to speak hard truths to a nation weary of President Obama's policies and ready to make a much-needed change.
"It's time to end this era of absentee leadership in the Oval Office and send real leaders to the White House," Mr. Christie said, according to prepared remarks. "America needs Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan, and we need them right now."
In delivering the keynote address at the Republican National Convention, Mr. Christie demonstrated his trademark bluntness -- crediting his mother for teaching him how to speak "without much varnish" -- but he did not lash out in personal ways at Mr. Obama, hardly mentioning the president by name. 
Instead, Mr. Christie reserved his sharp words for a tough contrast between the Republican approach to solving problems and a Democratic approach that he said would continue to fail to turn around the American economy and the country's broken political system. 
He accused Democrats of ignoring the truth about the country's economic difficulties and of wanting people to be coddled by "big government."
"Their plan: Whistle a happy tune while driving us off the fiscal cliff, as long as they are behind the wheel of power," Mr. Christie said.
Mr. Christie had been considered a top prospect to be Mr. Romney's running mate. He also briefly considered running for president himself this year, but ruled it out, concluding that he was not yet ready to assume the office.
The Romney campaign picked Mr. Christie to deliver the keynote address for his reputation as a straight-talking governor who has little patience for those who question his resolve.
But his aggressive style, which has led critics to brand him as a bully -- he has called people "stupid" and "idiots" -- was not on display in the hall. Nor was his anti-union fervor, which has emerged through his battles with the labor movement in his state.
Mr. Christie did offer some sharp jabs at Mr. Obama that whipped up the partisan crowd in the hall.
"It takes leadership that you don't get from reading a poll," Mr. Christie said, directing his remarks at Mr. Obama. "You see, Mr. President - real leaders don't follow polls. Real leaders change polls."
But primarily, the speech offered a challenge to the country to change course from an administration that he said was letting the nation's economy drift. He said the status quo must change, and he praised Mr. Romney as the right man to take the country in a different direction.
In describing the current crisis with the political system, Mr. Christie did not mince words or spare many, even those in his own party who he said had contributed to growing debt, a slowing economy and an inability to get anything done.
"Our leaders today have decided it is more important to be popular, to do what is easy and say 'yes,' rather than to say 'no' when 'no' is what's required," Mr. Christie said. "It's been easy for our leaders to say not us, and not now, in taking on the tough issues. And we've stood silently by, and let them get away with it."
Drawing on his two years as New Jersey's governor, Mr. Christie said the nation could do better. He said he had learned to work across the aisle with Democrats -- a claim that many in the other party would dispute.
He said that national politicians like Mr. Romney and his running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, must be willing to tell the hard truths to the American people about the future of popular entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security. Voters will reward them for it, he said.
"If you're willing to hear the truth about the hard road ahead, and the rewards for America that truth will bear, I'm here to begin with you this new era of truth-telling," he said.

HEADLINE: In Speech, Ann Romney Plays to the Heart

BYLINE: JONATHAN WEISMAN


HIGHLIGHT: Mrs. Romney used her prime-time speech at the Republican National Convention to try to take some of the sheen off her husband's glossy image. 

 BODY:
Ann Romney introduced her husband Tuesday night to the nation and to the Republican Party that had nominated him as president with a rousing speech that exhorted Americans, "You can trust Mitt."
"This man will not fail. This man will not let us down. This man will lift up America," she told the Republican National Convention to a series of sustained ovations, capped by the emergence of Mitt Romney from behind the stage for a quick, chaste kiss and the nominee's first acknowledgment of the convention.
Mrs. Romney used her prime-time speech to try to take some of the sheen off her husband's glossy image and to humanize Mr. Romney with the very real struggles he has faced with determination and inevitable success.
"I read somewhere that Mitt and I have a 'storybook marriage,'" she said. "Well, in the storybooks I read, there were never long, long rainy winter afternoons in a house with five boys screaming at once. And those storybooks never seemed to have chapters on M.S. or breast cancer."
"A storybook marriage? Nope, not at all," she said. "What Mitt Romney and I have is a real marriage." 
But despite her pledge to avoid politics and speak to the nation about love, Mrs. Romney hit most of the themes that her husband and his party have used to best President Obama: a flailing economy; struggling Americans, especially women; and a choice voters must make between failure and something new.
"We're too smart to know there aren't easy answers, but we're not dumb enough to accept that there aren't better answers," she said.
Mrs. Romney entered the hall with a difficult but critical task: Transfer some of her innate likability to her husband, who even Republicans readily concede lacks a natural bonhomie.
"The warmth just doesn't come out" on television, said Representative Brett Guthrie, Republican of Kentucky, who spent time with Mr. Romney for the first time two weeks ago and professed surprised at how nice he was.
Many delegates gathered in the convention hall said they didn't care if their nominee was "warm and fuzzy," as Donna Hamilton, 64, a Washington State delegate put it. But more professional politicians in the audience, like Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa, said the entire Romney family has this week to soften the nominee's edges and make him more accessible to independent and undecided voters.
Many of the struggles Mrs. Romney detailed were not so much his, but hers and his father's. She has multiple sclerosis and battled through breast cancer. The bootstrap section of the address belonged to George Romney, Mitt's father who, she reminded viewers, "never graduated from college," and instead "became a carpenter" and slogged his way to head a car company, then governor of Michigan.
But she did extol the determination of her husband.
"At every turn in his life, this man I met at a high school dance, has helped lift up others," she said. "He did it with the Olympics, when many wanted to give up. This is the man who will wake up every day with the determination to solve the problems that others say can't be solved, to fix what others say is beyond repair. This is the man who will work harder than anyone so that we can work a little less hard."
In a striking red dress, she walked out to a thunderous standing ovation. Pictures of a young Mr. Romney and his family were projected behind her. And the images of family ran throughout a speech overtly geared to women. For the moment, Mr. Romney's deficit with women has kept him tied or marginally behind Mr. Obama in most national polls. Tightening the gender gap is the key to a Romney victory in November.
"I love you, women," she shouted.
And she tried to set up a firewall against Democratic attacks on her husband's time at Bain Capital and the wealth he has amassed.
"Let's be honest, if the last four years had been successful, do we really think we'd be seeing these attacks on Mitt's success?" she asked.
