SECTION: Section C; Column 0; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 3210 words

HEADLINE: The Listings

 BODY:
Movies
Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.
&#x2605; 'Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry' (R, 1:31, in English and Mandarin) In December 2008 a 24-year-old American, Alison Klayman, as a favor to a friend, started videotaping the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei. Her timing was dazzling as was her perseverance, as becomes clear in this galvanizing portrait of the artist, his work and his times. (Manohla Dargis)
'The Amazing Spider-Man' (PG-13, 2:16) Five years after Sam Rami directed his third ''Spider-Man'' installment, Marc Webb returns this lucrative franchise to its origins with Andrew Garfield as the spider-teenager and Emma Stone as the girl. Painless but unnecessary. (Dargis)
'The Apparition' (PG-13, 1:22) Todd Lincoln's horror movie -- about two college grads minding a house overtaken by a specter newly escaped from an afterlife dimension -- is so slight it has an almost wraithlike nontexture itself. Blink and you'll miss it. But no great loss. (Andy Webster) 
&#x2605; 'Beasts of the Southern Wild' (PG-13, 1:33) A blast of joyful, chaotic emotion from the bayou, Benh Zeitlin's dazzling film is a homegrown magic-realist fable of defiance in the face of hardship. A community in a stretch of coastal Louisiana called the Bathtub is menaced by storms and government benevolence. Their ordeal is narrated by a young girl named Hushpuppy (Quvenzhané Wallis ), who lives with her father, Wink (Dwight Henry), and who belongs in the tradition of Huck Finn, Scout Finch, Eloise and other indomitable American child heroes. (A. O. Scott)
'Beloved' (No rating, 2:15, in French) Christophe Honoré's musical melodrama follows, over four decades, the complicated love lives of Madeleine (Ludivine Sagnier in the 1960s and '70s, Catherine Deneuve later) and her daughter, Vera (Chiara Mastroianni). Alex Beaupain's clever pop songs offer more commentary than emotion, but the long, meandering story is full of pathos, comedy and surprise. (Scott)
'The Bourne Legacy' (PG-13, 2:05) Less a thrilling franchise reboot than a solid salvage mission, the fourth installment of the ''Bourne'' spy series replaces Matt Damon with a sympathetic Jeremy Renner, who handles the action persuasively even if the fight sequences lack a sense of regret or even sorrow. As viewers are whisked from location to location, it feels as if the director, Tony Gilroy, is trying too hard to match the accelerated tempo of the previous films. (Dargis)
'Brave' (PG, 1:33) After 17 years of feature filmmaking, Pixar has -- ta-da! -- its first female protagonist, Merida, a brave, ginger-mopped princess who wants to chart her own fate. The animation, as might be expected, is beautiful, but the story is filled with dreary gender clichés. Mark Andrews and Brenda Chapman directed and helped write the script. (Dargis)
'The Campaign' (R, 1:25) Two nincompoops run against each other for a seat in Congress. It's not a documentary, but a silly, not very outrageous comedy starring Will Ferrell and Zach Galifianakis. (Scott)
'Celeste and Jesse Forever' (R, 1:31) This wistful romantic comedy about love, marriage and never wanting to say you're sorry stars the appealing Rashida Jones and Andy Samberg as a couple who've split up without moving on or out. Written by Ms. Jones and Will McCormack, it was directed by Lee Toland Krieger. (Dargis)
'Chicken With Plums' (PG-13, 1:33, in French) Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud follow ''Persepolis,'' their animated adaptation of Ms. Satrapi's autobiographical graphic novel, with a live-action rendering of a piece of her family's history. Mathieu Amalric plays Nasser Ali, a melancholy violinist in mid-20th-century Tehran whose romantic and artistic torment fuels an oddly gentle and contemplative melodrama. The large French-speaking cast includes Maria de Medeiros as Nasser's wife and Golshifteh Farahani as the great lost love of his youth. (Scott)
&#x2605; 'Compliance' (R, 1:30) Raising troubling questions about the influence of class and education on our response to authority, Craig Zobel's squirmy psychological horror movie, based on a series of hoaxes at fast-food restaurants nationwide, is a slow-motion punch to the groin. (Jeannette Catsoulis)
'Cosmopolis' (R, 1:48) David Cronenberg directs this cold, funny adaptation of the 2003 Don DeLillo novel starring Robert Pattinson as a zomboid billionaire, one of the limo riding masters of the universe who, over the course of a long day and night, loses a great deal and, by doing so, becomes human. (Dargis)
&#x2605; 'The Dark Knight Rises' (PG-13, 2:44) After seven years and two films that have pushed Batman (Christian Bale) ever deeper into the dark, the director Christopher Nolan has completed his postmodern, post-Sept. 11 epic of ambivalent good versus multidimensional evil with a burst of light. (Dargis)
'Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days' (PG, 1:34) This genial but not very ambitious installment of the ''Wimpy Kid'' franchise follows the young protagonist (Zachary Gordon) through a summer full of embarrassing moments involving camping, girl-chasing and more. Occasionally the predictable script finds a sweet spot, as in a scene in which some overly serious Civil War re-enactors get jolted out of their comfort zone. (Neil Genzlinger)
'Ek Tha Tiger' (No rating, 2:13, in Hindi) This Bollywood romance dressed up in espionage clothes has a ''my enemy, myself'' theme that is too tepid to resonate. Starring Salman Khan and Katrina Kaif, the movie feels most engaged during its glass-shattering, rooftop-hopping action sequences. (Rachel Saltz)
'The Expendables 2' (R, 1:43) Sylvester Stallone returns with his band of aging action stars and a ridiculous amount of ammunition and explosives, bent on avenging a comrade's death and keeping some plutonium out of evil hands. A brief appearance by Chuck Norris provides the best moment of self-parody in a movie that could have used a few more of them. (Genzlinger)
'First Position' (No rating, 1:30, in English, Spanish, French and Hebrew) The tears are often held tremulously back and the many hurts smiled away in Bess Kargman's appealing, largely upbeat documentary about young ballet dancers duking it out, sometimes on point and in tulle, for top honors at the Youth America Grand Prix. (Dargis)
'Hit & Run' (R, 1:40) In this weightless, silly car chase movie, Dax Shepard brings some charm to his role of a sweet-natured, shady goofball in the witness protection program. (Stephen Holden)
'Hope Springs' (PG-13, 1:32) While this film about a longtime marriage that's gone dry has modest charms to go with its well-matched and practiced pair of wily scene stealers -- Meryl Streep and Tommy Lee Jones working on screen together for the first time -- the industry will have to do better if it wants to persuade boomers that there's something for them at the local multiplex other than cartoons and clichés. (Dargis)
&#x2605; 'The Imposter' (R, 1:35) Slippery, manipulative and shamelessly entertaining, Bart Layton's bizarre true-crime documentary follows the twisty tale of a missing Texas teenager and the French-Algerian con artist who stole his identity. (Catsoulis)
'The Intouchables' (R, 1:52, in French) In this buddy movie from France, a rich white guy (François Cluzet), paralyzed from the neck down, is cared for by an African immigrant (Omar Sy) who teaches his boss to loosen up and appreciate life. The film's unabashed embrace of racial stereotypes may startle American audiences -- the movie was a huge hit in France -- but there is appealing warmth to the performances and an overall mood of friendly tolerance. It's embarrassing, but not as bad as it might have been. (Scott)
'Killer Joe' (NC-17, 1:43) Matthew McConaughey plays a psycho hired by the idiot son of an idiot family in this unfunny, self-indulgent violent bore. The director William Friedkin, working from the Tracy Letts play, is consistently controlled by the story's excesses rather than in control of them. (Dargis)
'Little White Lies' (No rating, 2:34, in French) Guillaume Canet's disappointing follow-up to his hit noir thriller, ''Tell No One,'' is a two-and-a-half-hour Gallic homage to ''The Big Chill'' and a protracted scolding to a group of self-absorbed overgrown yuppies. The strong ensemble cast includes François Cluzet, Jean Dujardin and Marion Cotillard. (Holden)
'Marvel's The Avengers' (PG-13, 2:22) Thor, the Hulk, Iron Man, Captain America and a few other mighty Marvel superheroes team up under the supervision of Samuel L. Jackson's Nick Fury in this franchise juggernaut, directed by Joss Whedon. The bantering and riffing among the characters provides some fun, but there is not much heart or imagination in the story or the action sequences. Which seems to satisfy the fans just fine. (Scott)
'The Matchmaker' (No rating, 1:52, in Hebrew) In Avi Nesher's film, which won several awards in Israel, a teenager's coming-of-age story of his experience working for a marital maven helps express the hopes and fears of a country awash in unsettling history. (Nicolas Rapold)
&#x2605; 'Moonrise Kingdom' (PG-13, 1:34) In Wes Anderson's latest, a wondrous storybook tale, a girl and a boy, both 12, run off to a remote inlet on an island where most of the adults seem disappointed and more than a little sad. The two are very serious -- about love, their plans, books, life itself -- and often act older than their age. You wonder what their hurry is, given that here adulthood, with its quarrels, regrets and anguished pillow talk, can feel as dangerous as the storm that's hurtling toward the island, ready to blow it all down. With Bill Murray, Bruce Willis and Frances McDormand. (Dargis)
&#x2605; 'Neighboring Sounds' (No rating, 2:11, in Portuguese) The Brazilian director Kleber Mendonça Filho's debut is a densely layered look at life on a wealthy block in the northeastern city of Recife. With humor, precision and quiet suspense, Mr. Mendonça lays bare the contradictions and ancient grievances that simmer below the shiny, prosperous surface of modern Brazil. (Scott)
'The Odd Life of Timothy Green' (PG, 1:45) In this baffling exercise in maudlin, whimsical surrealism, directed by Peter Hedges, a childless couple (Jennifer Garner and a miserable-looking Joel Edgerton) are visited by a magic plant in the shape of a 10-year-old boy (CJ Adams). Tears are shed and lessons are learned, the main one being that this would have worked better as a horror movie. (Scott)
&#x2605; 'ParaNorman' (PG, 1:33) This beautiful-looking, charmingly heartfelt 3-D stop-motion animation -- from the studio that produced ''Coraline'' -- centers on an 11-year-old boy who can see ghosts and, with frights and laughter, battles a spirit. Directed by Sam Fell and the movie's screenwriter, Chris Butler. (Dargis)
&#x2605; 'Premium Rush' (PG-13, 1:31) The director David Koepp provides about all the late summer air-conditioned relief you could hope for in this buoyant dumb-fun, ticking-clock thriller about a bicycle messenger (the dependably appealing Joseph Gordon-Levitt) who has to get from here to there without being taken out by cars or a bad cop (a terrific Michael Shannon). (Dargis)
&#x2605; 'The Queen of Versailles' (PG, 1:40) Lauren Greenfield's documentary follows the shifting fortunes of David and Jackie Siegel, a wealthy Florida couple who dreamed of building the biggest house in America. The movie, which starts out like smirky reality television, turns into something darker and more complex as economic troubles take a toll on the Siegels and the audience becomes better acquainted with them. It's like a Theodore Dreiser novel for our new gilded age. (Scott)
'Red Hook Summer' (R, 2:01) Spike Lee's celebration of African-American resilience in a struggling Brooklyn neighborhood is messy, meandering and bluntly polemical. But it has one crucial element: raw vitality. (Holden)
'Robot & Frank' (PG-13, 1:30) Jake Schreier directed, from a script by Christopher D. Ford, this eager-to-please story set in the near future about an elderly gent (Frank Langella), his robot (voiced by Peter Sarsgaard) and some awkwardly managed truths about old age. Susan Sarandon also stars. (Dargis)
'Samsara' (PG-13, 1:39) Ron Fricke's new film, like its predecessor, ''Baraka,'' is a free-associative tour of the world, a series of striking, sometimes surreal images of nature, work, life and death in the global economy. (Scott)
&#x2605; 'Searching for Sugar Man' (PG-13, 1:26) There are several entrancing mysteries circulating in Malik Bendjelloul's hugely appealing documentary about fans, faith and an enigmatic Age of Aquarius musician known as Rodriguez who burned bright and hopeful before disappearing. Don't wait for the DVD. (Dargis)
'Sleepwalk With Me' (No rating, 1:30) The surreal dream sequences in this screen adaptation of Mike Birbiglia's 2008 one-man show -- about a commitment-phobic stand-up comedian with a sleep disorder -- help make this likable movie more than a glorified stand-up act. (Holden)
'Somewhere Between' (No rating, 1:28, in English, Mandarin and Spanish) Effortlessly moving but frustratingly superficial, Linda Goldstein Knowlton's soft-focus profile of four bright Chinese girls and their adoptive American families substitutes upbeat interviews for sharp edges and contextual complexity. (Catsoulis)
'Sparkle' (PG-13, 1:56) It is impossible to watch this ramshackle remake of a 1976 movie and not relate its story to the life of Whitney Houston, who portrays the strict church-lady mother of an aspiring singer in late-1960s Detroit. (Holden)
'Step Up Revolution' (PG-13, 1:39) How to stop a greedy developer from gutting a Miami neighborhood? The power of dance, of course. The fourth film in the ''Step Up'' franchise has some dandy flash-mob-style dance numbers, though like its predecessors it is burdened by a predictable plot and unintentionally laughable dialogue. (Genzlinger)
'Ted' (R, 1:46) Seth MacFarlane, creator of ''The Family Guy,'' takes his provocative humor and his New England-accented voiceover skills to the big screen in this profane, sometimes funny comedy about a talking stuffed animal, the overgrown boy who loves him (Mark Wahlberg), and, somewhat tangentially, the boy's girlfriend (Mila Kunis) who wishes he would just grow up. (Scott)
'Teddy Bear' (No rating, 1:33, in Danish, English and Thai) Mads Matthiesen directs this low-key, sometimes funny and sweet Danish drama about a 38-year-old bodybuilder (Kim Kold), who in order to finally grow up, must learn to say hello to love and goodbye to dear old, horrible Mom. (Dargis)
'To Rome With Love' (R, 1:52) Woody Allen's latest is a mild, silly collection of tales set in the Italian capital, where love is complicated and characters -- both Italian and American -- are baffled, neurotic and always articulate. Mr. Allen plays a semi-retired opera promoter, while Jesse Eisenberg plays the younger Woody Allen type, torn between loyalty to his sensible girlfriend (Greta Gerwig) and her wayward, needy friend (Ellen Page). Alec Baldwin, Penélope Cruz and Roberto Benigni also contribute to this frothy, airy romp through some of Mr. Allen's favorite themes. (Scott)
'Total Recall' (PG-13, 1:58) Colin Farrell, Kate Beckinsale and Jessica Biel star in this chaotic and thoroughly unmemorable science-fiction action movie, loosely remade from a 1990 Arnold Schwarzenegger vehicle and even more loosely based on a story by Philip K. Dick. (Scott)
'2016: Obama's America' (PG, 1:33) Dinesh D'Souza -- the author of the best seller ''The Roots of Obama's Rage'' and a former American Enterprise Institute fellow -- is the host and narrator of this strident documentary, in which Mr. D'Souza enlists a host of interviewees who are almost entirely critical of the president. The film is unlikely to convert supporters of President Obama to an opposite view. (Webster)
'2 Days in New York' (R, 1:36) In this sequel to ''2 Days in Paris,'' Julie Delpy, who wrote and directed, reprises the role of Marion, a French photographer now living with Mingus (Chris Rock), a journalist and radio host. Their hectic, happy bohemian household is thrown into chaos by the arrival of Marion's father (Ms. Delpy's father, Albert), her sister Rose (Alexia Landeau) and Rose's boyfriend, Manu (Alexandre Nahon). The movie is spirited and sometimes hilarious, but turns sloppy and strained when it reaches for deeper emotional insights into its nutty characters. (Scott)
'The Watch' (R, 1:41) Half unfunny potty-mouthed buddy comedy, half spoof of ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers,'' this comic washout starring Ben Stiller and Vince Vaughn is larded with crude phallic jokes. (Holden)
Film Series
Baby Peggy: the Oldest Living Silent-Film Star Returns (Wednesday and Thursday, through Sept. 9) Born in 1918 and a performer from the age of 19 months, Diana Serra Cary appeared under the name Baby Peggy in a series of shorts and features released by Universal from 1919 to 1926, achieving a level of popularity equal to her male child-star counterpart, Jackie Coogan. Although she left the movie business in 1938, she has campaigned on behalf of better working conditions for child actors and has published several books, including her 1996 autobiography, ''What Ever Happened to Baby Peggy?'' She will be present on Wednesday at 6:30 p.m. to introduce Vera Iwerebor's 2010 documentary, ''Baby Peggy: The Elephant in the Room,'' and participate in a discussion with Ms. Iwerebor after the screening. The documentary will be repeated daily through Sept. 9, accompanied by a sampling of her surviving films. Museum of Modern Art Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters, (212) 708-9400, moma.org; $12. (Dave Kehr)
'The Bridge on the River Kwai' (Saturday and Sunday) The Museum of the Moving Image screens a new restoration of David Lean's 1957 World War II adventure set in a Japanese prison camp in Burma, where a group of detainees -- led by Alec Guinness, as a determined colonel -- are charged with constructing a strategically important railway bridge. William Holden, Jack Hawkins and Sessue Hayakawa also star in the film, with a screenplay by the blacklisted writers Carl Foreman and Michael Wilson, whose names did not appear on the film until a 1985 reissue. Presented in digital video (DCP) at 6:30 p.m., 35th Avenue at 37th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718) 784-0077, movingimage.us; $12. (Kehr)
James Bond No. 1: Sean Connery's 007 (Friday through Thursday) It's been 50 years since the first James Bond film, ''Dr. No,'' was released in 1962 (No. 23, ''Skyfall,'' will come out in November), an anniversary which naturally calls for a retrospective of the seven films starring the alpha-Bond, Sean Connery. ''Dr. No'' gets things rolling at 10:55 a.m. on Friday, with a different combination of films presented each day through Thursday. All will be shown in digital video (DCP) versions, except for the noncanonical 1983 ''Never Say Never Again'' (different producers, long story), which will be shown in 35 millimeter. On Sunday all seven films will be shown in order, beginning at 10:55 a.m., with tickets for the whole megillah priced at $40. IFC Center, 323 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-7771, ifccenter.com; $13. (Kehr)

HEADLINE: Al Jazeera, Seeking U.S. Viewers, Bets on Soccer

BYLINE: By KEN BELSON; Richard Sandomir and Jack Bell contributed reporting.

 BODY:
Al Jazeera, once known in the United States mostly for televising videos of Americans and others taken hostage in foreign countries, but now a serious presence as a worldwide network, is betting heavily on sports to win American viewers.
This month, an Al Jazeera subsidiary, beIN Sport, bought the rights to broadcast some of the United States national soccer team's games as it seeks to qualify for the 2014 World Cup. BeIN Sport has also paid heavily to show in the United States some of Europe's best soccer from Spain, Italy, France and England.
BeIN Sport's bold entry into the American market befits its deep-pocketed owners, who appear committed to becoming a major player in soccer, the globe's most popular sport. It could make an even bigger splash if it bids in the coming months for the rights to broadcast England's Premier League in the United States, where the league has a growing and devoted following, as well as Major League Soccer, whose broadcast rights expire in 2014. 
It is unclear whether the network's buying spree is designed to make money, to raise its global brand or to perhaps provide leverage to get United States exposure for its news network. To date, Al Jazeera's English-language news service has gained only a tiny foothold in the American market, but it could use its growing prominence in sports broadcasting to compel cable providers to carry its news programming.
Al Jazeera, based in Qatar, clearly has the resources to be a player. The network receives funds from the Qatari government, which spent lavishly to win the bid to host the World Cup in 2022.
''The old dinosaurs are dying off, and the new sports fans are more than willing to accept soccer,'' said Phil Schoen, an announcer who was hired by beIN Sport after stints at ESPN and GolTV. ''It's not just the ethnics, soccer moms and urban singles. To make such a commitment really says something about how beIN Sport feels about the future of the sport in this country.''
BeIN Sport declined to make available any executives to speak on the record about its broader strategy.
Initially, beIN Sport may cause headaches for United States soccer fans. So far, the network is carried only on DirecTV and Dish, the country's two largest satellite television providers, and Comcast, the country's largest cable network. But in many cases, customers will have to pay several dollars more a month to subscribe to an extra sports package that includes beIN Sport, which only a small fraction of customers do.
While beIN Sport is rushing to sign other distribution deals, it may be months if not years before fans throughout the country can see the network in their homes. Until then, many fans will have to find a local bar to see the American national team play World Cup qualifying games on the road, including matches against Jamaica in Kingston on Sept. 7 and in Antigua on Oct. 12.
Quickly, beIN Sport has upended the sports television landscape. The network is committed to covering international sports like soccer, rugby, volleyball and track and field. In that sense, it is unlikely to rival ESPN, CBS or the other major American networks that pay billions of dollars to carry baseball, football and basketball.
But in spending heavily for the rights to Europe's top soccer leagues and some of the United States national team's games, beIN Sport threatens to dominate a fast-growing market populated by Fox Sports, ESPN and GolTV. That is bad news for those networks, but great news for soccer teams, leagues and federations.
According to one television executive, beIN paid twice as much as what GolTV had paid to broadcast La Liga, the top Spanish soccer league. BeIN Sport has reportedly paid Comcast to be carried to the cable company's 22 million television subscribers, rather than being paid by Comcast, the way ESPN and Fox are. BeIN Sport also paid well above market rates for the rights to the United States World Cup qualifiers.
''There is a maxim that a small distributor will pay more for rights than a large one because it means more to them,'' said Neal H. Pilson, a former president of CBS Sports who is a consultant. ''In a world with thousands of channels, live sports are a means of growing an existing business or launching a new business.''
Mr. Schoen, beIN Sport's new announcer, said he was unaware whether his new employer would try to acquire the United States rights to England's Premier League when they come up for bid. Industry executives expect those rights to fetch twice as much as what Fox paid for them three years ago, or far more if beIN Sport joins the bidding.
''If the soccer industry in the U.S. remains a business driven by economics, I think everyone will be successful,'' said Rodrigo Lombello, the chief operating officer of GolTV, which was outbid by beIN Sport for the United States rights to Spain's top league games. ''But if the industry is going to be a toy for the sheik from Qatar, then I don't know what will happen.''
Fox, which now broadcasts Premier League games in the United States, is eager to defend its turf, especially after spending heavily to win the rights to broadcast the World Cups in 2018 and 2022. Losing the Premier League, the world's most popular, would be a blow.
Fox argues that it is a better fit for the Premier League than beIN Sport because it can broadcast games to most homes in America, not just a few million homes that buy special sports packages. Last season, Fox set viewership records when it showed Premier League matches on Sundays while other networks were broadcasting N.F.L. games.
''Bottom line, there's always been competition in this field,'' said David Nathanson, the general manager of Fox Soccer. ''It just so happens that as the sport of soccer has grown in the U.S., you're bound to have more players interested in it. But we're the only dedicated English-language soccer network today, so it plays to our strength.''
Longer term, the question many television executives are asking is what Al Jazeera and the Qataris hope to accomplish with beIN Sport. Are they trying to tap the seemingly unending interest in soccer and sports? Are they trying to promote Qatar ahead of the World Cup in 2022? Or do they want to use beIN Sport as a wedge to get cable and satellite providers to carry Al Jazeera's news channel, which has had trouble getting carried in the United States because, some suggest, of the hostility to the network's programming?
BeIN Sport is careful to note that it operates independently of Al Jazeera's news division and, thus far, has focused only on buying sports rights. But other networks have used sports to promote their other programming. Nearly two decades ago, Fox shocked the sports world when it paid top dollar to show the N.F.L. Despite early losses, Fox gained wider coverage for its broadcast network.
Al Jazeera may be trying to pull a page from Fox's playbook. Some industry executives say that while the Qataris are perceived to have limitless resources, they may be doing what other networks have done before them: spending heavily to break into a crowded market.
''My experience is they are more economically driven than you would think and they have a very westernized philosophy,'' said Rob Tilliss, a sports consultant who advises clients in the Middle East.
The common perception that cable operators are reluctant to do business with Al Jazeera is incorrect, he said. ''It's a commercial relationship, and the more I go over there, the more I realize that,'' he said. ''At the end of the day, their objectives are basically the same.''

HEADLINE: Death Penalty Sought in Murder Trial of 3 Soldiers

BYLINE: By ROBBIE BROWN

 BODY:
ATLANTA -- Prosecutors will seek the death penalty against three soldiers in Georgia accused of killing a fellow soldier and his girlfriend and plotting terrorist attacks at their own military base.
District Attorney Tom Durden of Long County said on Thursday that the suspects would face charges of malice murder, felony murder and criminal gang activity. The soldiers, Pvt. Isaac Aguigui, Sgt. Anthony Peden and Pvt. Christopher Salmon, have not entered pleas.
They are accused of killing a former soldier, Michael Roark, 19, and his girlfriend, Tiffany York, 17, on Dec. 4. Prosecutors say the soldiers were all members of a small anarchist militia called FEAR, or Forever Enduring Always Ready, that plotted the overthrow of Fort Stewart, home of the Army's Third Infantry Division, about 40 miles southwest of Savannah. 
Prosecutors say the militia group comprised an unknown number of active and former members of the military. The group contemplated several attacks, including poisoning the apple crop in Washington State, attacking a dam and assassinating President Obama. The group spent at least $87,000 buying guns and bomb components.
But the militia began to unravel when one of its members, Mr. Roark, who had left the Army as a private, was caught taking money and planned to leave the group, prosecutors say. On Monday, one of the accused conspirators, Pfc. Michael Burnett, told a judge that the couple had been killed to protect the militia's secrecy. Private Burnett took a plea deal, confessing to voluntary manslaughter for a lighter sentence.
''I don't know how it got to the point where two people got murdered,'' Private Burnett told Judge Robert L. Russell III of Long County Superior Court. ''If I could have stopped this from happening, I would have.''
The plot shook the small, rural community in south Georgia that houses Fort Stewart, the largest Army installation east of the Mississippi River. The charges come just a week after two members of a different militia were sentenced in a separate terrorist scheme in north Georgia, a plot to release deadly chemicals and bomb federal buildings in Atlanta.
Those are only the latest and most visible examples of the rise in violent militia groups in recent years, said Mark Potok, an authority on the groups and the editor of the Southern Poverty Law Center's Intelligence Report. In 2011, the center identified 1,274 groups as part of the so-called patriot and militia movements, up from 824 the year before.
Mr. Potok said the rise was exacerbated by the economic recession and antagonism toward Mr. Obama.
On Monday, an Alaska couple who are members of a militia pleaded guilty to charges of conspiring to kill a federal judge in what prosecutors said was a revenge plot over income-tax rulings against them.
In 2011, a man with ties to militia groups was charged with plotting to bomb a Martin Luther King Day parade in Spokane, Wash.
''It's been remarkable how these kinds of events have piled up, faster and faster,'' Mr. Potok said. ''When you listen to the details of this plot, you'd think they're all on hallucinogens. It would be easy not to take them seriously were it not for the fact that two people are dead.''
On Thursday, the courtroom in rural Long County was a scene of repeated outbursts. The stepfather of Ms. York, Wesley Thomas, lunged at one of the defendants. Later, a family member of Mr. Roark yelled curse words at another defendant.
Private Burnett testified that the couple was killed to protect the militia. On Dec. 4, he said, the soldiers lured Mr. Roark and Ms. York to a forest a short distance from the Army post by telling them that they were going target shooting. He said Sergeant Peden shot Ms. York in the head while she was trying to get out of her car. He said Private Salmon shot Mr. Roark twice in the head.
The authorities are also investigating whether one of the suspects, Private Aguigui, may have played a role in another killing. His wife was discovered dead in July 2011 in Wenatchee, Wash., and the death has not been explained.
Prosecutors say that Private Aguigui received up to $500,000 in life insurance benefits after his wife's death and that he used the money to finance the militia.
PHOTOS: Wesley Thomas, left, was restrained after he lunged at a man accused of killing his stepdaughter.; From left, Christopher Salmon, Isaac Aguigui and Anthony Peden were in court on Thursday. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY STEPHEN MORTON/ASSOCIATED PRESS)

HEADLINE: Spare Times

BYLINE: By ANNE MANCUSO

 BODY:
Labor Day Weekend
New York City
BRAZILIAN DAY CELEBRATION (Saturday and Sunday) Everyone is Brazilian -- at least for this annual weekend of Brazilian culture and food. Kicking off the event on Saturday is the Lavagem da Rua 46 (the Cleansing of West 46th Street), during which performers dressed in white will sweep to music on what is known as Little Brazil Street. The festivities will begin at 46th Street and Times Square, and will proceed to a stage at Madison Avenue and 46th Street, where music will be played till 4 p.m. On Sunday the celebration continues from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., along Avenue of the Americas, from 43rd to 57th Streets, and 46th Street, between Madison and Seventh Avenues, with stages set up at Avenue of the Americas at 43rd Street and Madison Avenue at 46th Street. Complete event details are at brazilianday.com. 
GREAT NORTH RIVER TUGBOAT RACE AND COMPETITION (Sunday) Who needs ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' when we have the tugboats of the Hudson? This annual event -- the 20th -- includes a parade, tugboat races and pulling competitions as well as land-based contests in spinach eating and line throwing. Much of the action will be centered on Piers 83 and 84, at the Hudson River and West 43rd and 44th Streets. Following a parade at 10 a.m. from the area to the waters near 79th Street, the tugboats will race back to 44th Street at 10:30 a.m. and engage in contests beginning at 11 a.m. (A Circle Line cruise will follow the action; it leaves at 9:30 a.m. from Pier 83 and costs $30, or $25 for children under 14; it's free for children 4 and younger.) All activities except the boat ride are free; sponsors include the Working Harbor Committee and Friends of Hudson River Park, with support from Circle Line Sightseeing Cruises and the New York City Economic Development Corporation; workingharbor.org.
LABOR HISTORY WALKING TOURS (Saturday through Monday) These tours focus on the labor history of Greenwich Village, with stops at sites associated with events like the first Labor Day parade and the Triangle Waist Company fire, and those significant in the lives of activists like Emma Goldman and John Reed. The tours sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours, on Saturday and Sunday at 2 p.m., will also combine a sampling of desserts. It costs $26, which includes treats; for reservations and meeting place: (212) 465-3331. On Monday an outing led by Big Onion Walking Tours will meet at 11 a.m. on the northeast corner of Washington Square North and Fifth Avenue; $18, or $15 for 63+ and students; (888) 606-9255; bigonion.com.
'RICHARD III' (Friday through Sunday) This tragic monarch holds forth on the north patio behind the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument at Riverside Drive and West 89th Street for the last free performances of the Hudson Warehouse's outdoor production of this Shakespeare play. Shows begin at 6:30 p.m., with cushioned seating available on nearby stairs and benches; hudsonwarehouse.net.
VILLAGE STREET FAIRS (Saturday and Sunday) The Andrew Glover Youth Program Street Fair takes place on Saturday on Fourth Avenue, between 8th and 14th Streets. On Sunday the Broadway Street Fair, sponsored by the Greenwich Village Chamber of Commerce, will line Broadway from Waverly Place to 14th Street. Both go on from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
WASHINGTON SQUARE OUTDOOR ART EXHIBIT (Saturday through Monday) This semiannual display will line University Place, from East 12th Street along the southern and eastern sides of Washington Square Park to Third Street, from noon to 6 p.m.; also on Sept. 8 and 9; (212) 982-6255, wsoae.org.
WEST INDIAN AMERICAN DAY CARNIVAL 2012 (Monday) The 45th anniversary of this Brooklyn celebration of West Indian pride will fill Eastern Parkway, from Schenectady Avenue to the Flatbush Avenue Extension, with music, dancing and food from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; warm-up shows will take place throughout the weekend; (718) 467-1797, wiadca.com.
YACHT CRUISE FUND-RAISER (Saturday) A sunset cruise of Manhattan, with dinner, music and dancing, is planned from 6:30 to 11 p.m. on the Skyline Princess. Participants are asked to dress in white. Tickets are $125, with proceeds benefiting the Nepperhan Community Center in Yonkers. The boat leaves from the World's Fair Marina, in Queens; (914) 965-0203, nepperhancc.com.
Upstate
AMERICAN ROOTS FESTIVAL (Monday) This annual festival -- the fourth sponsored by the Turning Point Cafe -- will run from noon to 6 p.m. at the Goswick Pavilion/Rittenberg Ball Field, 95 Ferry Road, Piermont. Those taking part include the Lucky Peterson Band, the John WhoEver Trio and the Nutopians. Tickets are $15 (free for 12 and younger) with a portion of the proceeds to benefit the Piermont Police Athletic League. Spectators should take along seating, but leave the pets at home. (845) 359-1089, turningpointcafe.com.
GREEN CORN FESTIVAL (Saturday through Monday) As sure as the approach of the fall harvest, this celebration of the traditions and culture of the American Indians of the Hudson Valley takes place at Philipsburg Manor, part of Historic Hudson Valley, at 381 North Broadway in Sleepy Hollow. There will be performances, crafts workshops and demonstrations of open-hearth cooking. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., (914) 631-8200, hudsonvalley.org; $14; $12 for 62+; $8 for 3 to 17; and free for those under 3 and members.
HOLIDAY EVENTS AT WEST POINT (Sunday) Activities planned at the Trophy Point Amphitheater include Civil War re-enactments beginning at 1 p.m. and evening concerts featuring the Jazz Knights at 6:30 p.m. and the Concert Band at 8 p.m. There will also be fireworks and a cannon salute. The raindate is Monday. (845) 938-2617, usma.edu/band. Concertgoers should call on the day to confirm; photo ID is required.
KAYAK TOURS (Friday through Monday) Water lovers can choose from a number of excursions offered by Hudson River Recreation, including a moonlight tour on the Croton River on Friday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m.; or sunset tours on the Hudson River on Saturday at 6 p.m. Tickets range from $20 to $99 and reservations are required; (914) 682-5135, kayakhudson.com.
NEW YORK RENAISSANCE FAIRE (Saturday through Monday) Special events are planned for the 35th edition of this celebration of medieval arts at Sterling Forest, 600 Route 17A, Tuxedo. On Saturday and Sunday a ''Fantasy Weekend'' will offer visits by creatures from stories and legends, and on Monday, Vikings and others are expected to descend upon the fairground during a ''Barbarian Invasion.'' From 10 a.m. to 7 p.m., (845) 351-5171, renfair.com; $20 in advance, $10 for ages 5 to 12, free for under 5; $22 and $11 at the gate.
NEW CITY STREET FAIR (Sunday) An annual celebration with entertainment, rides and games, from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. at South Main Street and Congers Road. Sponsored by the New City Chamber of Commerce.
WOODSTOCK-NEW PALTZ ARTS & CRAFTS FAIR (Saturday through Monday) The fall edition of this crafts extravaganza will take place, as usual, at the Ulster County Fairgrounds, 249 Libertyville Road in New Paltz. Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Monday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., (845) 679-8087, quailhollow.com; $8; $7 for 62+; free for children under 12.
Long Island
CRAFTS SHOWS ( Saturday and Sunday) In Amagansett, a Fine Arts & Crafts Show is planned for Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., at the American Legion, 15 Montauk Highway; (610) 486-6393, amagansettartsandcrafts.com. In East Meadow, the show is from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. both days at Field 8 of Eisenhower Park, Stewart and Merrick Avenues; (516) 442-6000, nassaucountycraftshows.com. The Seaford Railroad Station, on Sunrise Highway, off Route 135, is the site of a show Saturday through Monday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., sponsored by Showtiques; (631) 724-5966, showtiques.com. HEADLINE: Big Plans for the Future (Including a Roof, One Day)

BYLINE: By GREG BISHOP

 BODY:
The first four days of the United States Open unfolded without public protests from the players, without damage from a hurricane, with few upsets and only one brief rain delay. The biggest news was a pair of retirements -- from Andy Roddick and Kim Clijsters -- and for a tournament in transition, that was a good thing, a knock-on-wood thing.
On Thursday, the focus remained on the tennis. Fifth-seeded Jo-Wilfried Tsonga lost, and unseeded Jack Sock won again. Mardy Fish roared back from two sets down to defeat Nikolay Davydenko to help set an Open record, with 10 such comebacks already completed in 2012. 
For four days, complaints centered on the absence of an injured Rafael Nadal and the lack of compelling night matches, each, it seemed, shorter and less competitive than the last. Meanwhile, the grounds filled, the cash registers clanged and the tournament continued without international incident.
As the new Open tournament director, David Brewer observed all this through 18-hour workdays, his focus as much on the future as the present. He joined the United States Tennis Association in 1997, and by the conclusion of the 2011 tournament, with Tropical Storm Irene and a cracked court and another Monday men's singles final and players that lamented their lack of voice, Brewer, it seemed, had seen it all.
However, in an interview before the tournament, Brewer described this year and next year as a period of unprecedented change, the most since the U.S.T.A. built Arthur Ashe Stadium in 1997.
Courts will be moved. Louis Armstrong Stadium will be torn down and rebuilt. Capacity will be added. Amenities will be improved. A day of rest will be added between the men's semifinals and final. Officials even dared this week to say definitively that Ashe would one day have a roof. On the matter of which day, of course, they remained uncertain.
''There is nothing that compares to this,'' Brewer said. ''We need to make the tournament better. We understand that things are changing. We're doing that.''
Asked if he found the overhaul daunting, Brewer shook his head. ''Frankly, this piece of it is pretty exciting,'' he said.
As Brewer talked, his two cellphones buzzed with phone calls and text messages and e-mails, the quantity indicative of the work ahead.
His background prepared Brewer for this moment. He played at Carson-Newman (Tenn.), a big server who ''never hit more than four ground strokes in my life.''
He started as a tennis professional at Nick Bollettieri's academy, a glorified ball feeder according to Brewer's recollection. He worked in sports marketing for Adidas when Ivan Lendl was among the company's biggest endorsers.
Now, he is the director of America's most prestigious tournament. ''People don't understand how big and complex this thing is,'' Brewer said. ''We used to have a boss that said it's like running 14 straight Super Bowls. And, frankly, that's a pretty good analogy.''
The Open is about to get bigger, more complex. On Sunday, Gordon Smith, chief operating officer of the U.S.T.A., and other officials showed a small group of reporters their renovation plans. Two words adorned the first slide.
The future, it read.
While weather delays in recent years forced the focus onto the absence of a roof, the plan includes the entire grounds, of which the roof is only one part. Louis Armstrong Stadium and the accompanying grandstand, Smith noted, are both more than 50 years old and ''beyond their useful life.'' Both will be replaced, and the grandstand will be moved from the northeast corner of the grounds to the underutilized southwest.
Additional plans call for an increase in capacity for day sessions by 10,000, expanded public plazas and promenades, and more viewing areas for the practice courts. Even a roof, they insisted, when technology allows.
Officials said they commissioned a study to measure the economic impact of the Open in New York. For 2010, the impact registered at $756 million, compared with $420 million in 2001 and $145 million in 1991.
To improve, the goal is to finish those renovations, except the roof, by the end of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's administration, or the end of next year. To that end, the more days like Thursday, the better, for both Open officials and the thousands who attend their tournament.
Late in the afternoon, the plaza outside Ashe was so crowded that fans jockeyed for the seats that opened up. Lines snaked around the outer courts, with crowds waiting to get in. Strangers debated the star potential of Sloane Stephens, discussed the serve speed of John Isner and wondered whether an American would ever win the men's tournament again.
No one talked about rain, or Monday finals, or natural disasters headed toward New York. They talked about a mostly uneventful Open that was notable for other, more pertinent reasons.
Like, you know, the tennis.

HEADLINE: GTT

BYLINE: By MICHAEL HOINSKI. 
mhoinski@texasmonthly.com

 BODY:
Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
COLLEGE STATION
Gator Raid
The Texas A&M football team has had nine months to recuperate after its last regular-season game in the Big 12 -- a stunning last-second loss to Texas in what appears to be the final game in a rivalry that lasted more than a century.
On Saturday the Aggies begin a new chapter in their new conference: the perennially tough S.E.C. They will kick off conference play against the No. 23-ranked Florida Gators, coached by Will Muschamp, who helped the Longhorns beat the Aggies twice in his three years as defensive coordinator for U.T. He has since denigrated College Station, telling a group of Florida boosters: ''You ever been to College Station? It'll be the only time you go.'' 
If you can snag a ticket to the sold-out game, you're likely to witness a battle. The cadets will be in full force, 12th-man towels will be waving, and Kevin Sumlin, the new head coach, will have the troops rallied.
Kyle Field, Sept. 8, 2:30 p.m., aggieathletics.com
DALLAS
Swing Set
Damon Gray was 4 when he realized he had vocal chops. ''I was in the car, going down the road, and I was singing a Hank Sr. song, 'Your Cheatin' Heart,' '' he recalled. ''And my mom said, 'Well, you sound just like him.' ''
Fast-forward to adulthood and Mr. Gray, a resident of Nashville who grew up in the Panhandle, is singing in the Great Recession Orchestra, the Duncanville-based western-swing big band that plays its own version of songs popularized by Bob Wills and Milton Brown, Texan pioneers of the hillbilly-jazz sound. This will be the first time the entire supergroup, whose numerous members hail from across the state and beyond, have played together live since forming a couple of years ago.
They will perform songs from the albums ''Have You Ever Even Heard of Milton Brown?'' and ''Double Shot,'' with free barbecue on the side.
It will be redemption for Mr. Gray, who had a recording contract that expired a decade ago because his Nashville label thought he was ''too country.''
''Nashville has ruined real country music,'' he said. ''And Texas still loves it.''
Sons of Hermann Hall, Aug. 31, 8 p.m., newtexrecords.net
MARFA
Sunny Side Up
It is hard to ignore the reality of climate change when most of the country is gripped by a drought.
''People have come to accept that we're entering an era of extreme weather,'' said Hamilton Fish, the New York publisher and entrepreneur. ''What they haven't done on either the civic or legislative level is translate that consciousness into action.''
To change that, Mr. Fish and Fairfax Dorn, co-founder of Ballroom Marfa, will host ''Marfa Dialogues: Politics and Culture of Climate and Sustainability,'' a symposium bringing together local and international figures.
Michael Pollan and Rebecca Solnit, both socially minded authors, will speak. The artist Cynthia Hopkins will perform ''This Clement World,'' her musical about ''sailing through the burning ice and myths of the high Arctic.'' And the curator David Buckland will introduce Carbon 13, an exhibit to help audiences understand the concept of the carbon footprint.
The far-flung West Texas location, though a cultural haven, was chosen with purpose. ''We always think that we have access to these huge networks and we can operate at a much more expansive level,'' Mr. Fish said. ''And we tend to forget the importance of acting locally.''
Various locations, Aug. 31-Sept. 2, various times, ballroom marfa.org
FORT WORTH
That's Gross
Nose pickers -- partakers in the pastime of mucus excavation -- will find like-minded souls at the last weekend of ''Grossology: The (Impolite) Science of the Human Body,'' an exhibition based on the ''Grossology'' series of children's books by Sylvia Branzei, which are dedicated to the body's sometimes unpleasant functions.
But adults will have fun, too, exploring creative displays like ''Patients Please,'' a variation of the board game Operation, and ''Y U Stink,'' a challenge to visitors to match body odors with body parts.
Fort Worth Museum of Science and History, Aug. 31-Sept. 3, various times, fortworth museum.org
ALPINE
Torch Song
Seeing hot-air balloons against the West Texas mountains during the Big Bend Balloon Bash could blow you away, a nd if not, there's the Fire Concert, in which ballooners scorch the night sky by playing ''music'' with their burners.
Alpine-Casparis Airport, Sept. 1-3, 7 a.m., bigbendballoon bash.com
GALVESTON
Keg Stand
Although Texas legislators have been reluctant to loosen distribution laws in the state's booming craft-beer business, making merry at the Brew Masters Craft Beer Festival would be a show of support that might convince them otherwise.
Moody Gardens, Aug. 31-Sept. 2, various times, brewmasters internationalbeerfestival.com

LENGTH: 968 words

HEADLINE: Saying It's Time to Leave, Yale President Will Retire

BYLINE: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

 BODY:
Richard C. Levin, who has directed a vast expansion and modernization of Yale University while improving university finances and relations with the city of New Haven, announced on Thursday that he would retire as president at the end of the school year, after 20 years. Dr. Levin is currently the most senior president in the Ivy League and one of the longest-serving in Yale's history. The university is expected to undertake a nationwide search for a successor, who will take the helm next summer at an elite institution with a global reputation and a $3 billion annual operating budget.
Dr. Levin, 65, said in an interview that he simply felt it was time to move on, that he planned to take a yearlong sabbatical to write a book and that he did not know what he would do after that. He noted that the university faced several big, potentially expensive, strategic choices, including how to pursue online education and whether to resume building projects that were delayed during the recession. 
''It makes sense to let someone who's got a horizon of 7 to 10 years, at least, to take those over,'' he said.
When Dr. Levin took office, Yale was being described as a university whose perch among the world's top educational institutions had grown shaky. The administration often battled the faculty and the troubled surrounding city, there were budget shortfalls and staff cuts, applications were down and facilities badly needed renovation and repair.
A search committee repeatedly postponed the deadline for naming a new president, reportedly settling unenthusiastically on the low-key Dr. Levin after being unable to find a more famous and charismatic leader. Almost two decades later, Yale's reputation and its finances are more secure, and Dr. Levin, commonly called Rick, is among the most admired university leaders in the country.
Under his presidency, the university has greatly expanded its academic facilities, including new quarters for science and medicine and a new business school campus; has overhauled its buildings, including all 12 undergraduate residential colleges; has started construction of two residential colleges to make room for the first major expansion in undergraduate enrollment in decades; and has embarked on new programs overseas.
''Rick's presidency hasn't been revolutionary,'' said Anthony Kronman, a former law school dean. ''It's been a steady, persistent accumulation that, I would say, add up to a massive set of achievements.''
Dr. Levin's administration has increased Yale's endowment faster than those of its peers, despite heavy capital spending; as of mid-2011, it stood at $19.4 billion, second only to Harvard's. His base salary of more than $1 million, and total compensation of more than $1.6 million, made him the highest-paid Ivy League president and one of the highest in the country.
After decades of discord, Dr. Levin set out to improve relations with New Haven -- he said his first act as president would be to shake the mayor's hand. The university gave financial assistance to employees who bought homes in New Haven, and it invested in the city's efforts to revive the commercial core.
''Yale was a campus that physically and metaphorically relied on hard edges -- hard edges around the campus and hard edges in relationships with the community,'' said John DeStefano Jr., the mayor since 1994. ''With Rick, those edges have become very soft.''
Benno C. Schmidt Jr., president from 1986 to 1992, battled faculty members over his moves to take decision-making powers away from them, over his plans to make deep cuts in their ranks and over other issues. Hired from Columbia University and maintaining his residence in New York City, Mr. Schmidt was derided as an outsider.
Faculty relations quickly improved under Dr. Levin, a familiar, well-liked and calming presence, and a longtime Yale professor and administrator whose wife, Jane, was an English professor there.
Perhaps the most serious clash with the faculty occurred this year, after Yale joined with the National University of Singapore to create a campus in Singapore. Professors protested the university's collaboration with an autocratic government and the fact that the faculty had not been consulted, but the project continues.
Yale's history of combative labor relations continued under Dr. Levin, with two strikes by clerical, maintenance and service employees in 1996 and two more in 2002 and 2003. But since then, relations have gone fairly smoothly with those employees, and Yale reached a new contract with them in June. The university has fought a longstanding effort to form a union by graduate students who teach or do research.
Dr. Levin's administration was also criticized in recent years by women's groups who said the university was slow to recognize that it needed to be tougher on sexual harassment and sexual assault. Last year, the university overhauled its procedures and suspended a fraternity that had been involved in harassment episodes.
Private universities have come under fire for their fast-rising prices; under Dr. Levin, the cost for a year of undergraduate education at Yale -- including tuition, books and room and board -- has more than doubled, to $58,600 for 2012-13. But most students receive financial aid, and Yale was among the first, in recent years, to replace student loans with grants and to extend significant aid to students from middle- and upper-middle-income families.
The top administrators that Dr. Levin has groomed have gone on to hold major posts elsewhere in academia -- presidents of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Duke University, Swarthmore College and Colgate University, and vice chancellors at Cambridge and Oxford Universities.
PHOTO: Richard C. Levin, 65, said he planned to write a book. (PHOTOGRAPH BY MUNSHI AHMED/BLOOMBERG NEWS)

HEADLINE: Quietly Ferocious Requiem for the Land

BYLINE: By KEN JOHNSON

 BODY:
NEW HAVEN -- A prophet in the wilderness of modernity, the photographer Robert Adams has devoted almost five decades to decrying what fecklessly industrious humans have done to the landscape of the American West.
''Robert Adams: The Place We Live,'' a splendid retrospective exhibition of more than 250 prints dating from the 1960s to 2009 at the Yale University Art Gallery here, surveys an oeuvre that is as compelling for its understated style as for its moral ferocity. Accompanied by a beautiful three-volume catalog produced by Yale University Press in collaboration with Mr. Adams, the exhibition was organized by Joshua Chuang, the gallery's assistant curator of photographs, and Jock Reynolds, its director. 
The work that put Mr. Adams on the map of modern photography in the '60s and helped start the movement known as the New Topographics may not look like that of a fire-breathing scourge. His sharply focused black-and-white imagery documenting housing construction in Colorado appears dispassionately objective, as if made by an insurance adjuster. But it is animated by spiritual exasperation. Where buffalo and Indians used to roam, there is suburban sprawl; where forests of majestic, centuries-old trees once grew, giant machines process scientifically engineered plantings into lumber for more tract housing. Where there was nature of abundance and fertility, there is a culture of banality, exploitation and waste. That is the big picture conjured by nearly all of Mr. Adams's efforts.
What may have seemed aesthetically indifferent in his work -- compared to that of, say, Ansel Adams (no relation) -- was actually the product of a Shaker-like sensibility acutely attuned to economies of form and metaphor. One of his best-known pictures, ''Colorado Springs, Colorado'' (1968), is a straight-ahead shot of an ordinary ranch house whose front window frames the silhouette of a woman backlit by a luminous rear window. This perfect moment exudes an aching loneliness, the boxed-in isolation of the stranded suburbanite.
Mr. Adams's biography reads like that of an admirable character in a novel by Marilynne Robinson. Born in New Jersey in 1937, he moved west with his family at the age of 10, first to Wisconsin and then to the outskirts of Denver. A churchgoing Boy Scout, he considered becoming a minister before veering into English literature, in which he earned a doctorate. He was teaching English at Colorado College in the early '60s when he took up photography. He has been married since 1960 to Kerstin Mornestam, who collaborates with him in the editing of his books; they have lived in Oregon since 1997.
Mr. Adams arrived at his near-minimalist style early but explored more familiar territory at the same time. In images from the late '60s and early '70s of fast-food joints, truck stops, bleak hotel rooms, roadside litter and a garbage truck painted in stars and stripes, Mr. Adams joined photographers like Robert Frank, Ed Ruscha and Garry Winogrand among countless others in sampling the low end of American culture. One clever photograph taken by Mr. Adams in Denver shows a sign for the Orchid Beauty Academy on a bleak commercial strip in Denver. But in the long run Mr. Adams was not to be satisfied with witty pot shots.
An image of a truck-size stack of lumber wrapped in black plastic shot in Denver in the early '70s is pure Adams. It could hardly be less picturesque, yet it has a particular metaphorical resonance in light of the fact that American soldiers were continuing to return home from Vietnam in black body bags. I don't know if Mr. Adams intended that association, but it has a funereal vibe.
There are other, less painful moods in the exhibition. A series from the '70s and early '80s called ''Summer Nights'' consists of nocturnal images of quiet neighborhoods with trees silhouetted by streetlights and dark houses, as if they are asleep. The invisible photographer lurks the deserted streets like the ghost of Edward Hopper.
People are relatively rare in Mr. Adams's work, but a notable exception is a series called ''Our Parents, Our Children,'' shot in parking lots baked by remorseless sunlight. These mainly show women with babies and young children getting in and out of cars and going to and from big-box stores. They are heartbreaking in their ordinariness. In an especially touching one a beaming, impossibly tiny girl stands on the hood of a car in a long dress, reaching up with both arms to a grandfatherly man who seems gigantic next to her.
The point of that series may be lost on viewers who skip Mr. Adams's brief introductory statement in the catalog explaining that detonators for nuclear bombs were then in production at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver. He wrote, ''Armaments built at risk to Denver become part of a worldwide system so open to error and malfunction that it is reasonable to believe many of us will, at a scarcely imaginable but exact time, die from them.''
As a photographer Mr. Adams loves trees more than people, and old trees most of all. ''Cottonwoods'' (1994), one of more than 30 books of thematic photographic essays he has published, is devoted to the defense of one beloved species. ''Agribusiness now wages war on cottonwoods,'' Mr. Adams wrote, ''because the trees compete for water, and suburban developers replace them with conveniently small but ecologically disruptive species like Russian olive.''
Images in the exhibition from his book ''Turning Back'' (2005) document the effects of clearcutting by the logging industry in Oregon. Many of them suggest the aftermath of a terrific explosion.
''Is there a relationship,'' Mr. Adams asks, ''between clearcutting and war, the landscape of one being in some respects like the landscape of the other? Does clearcutting originate in disrespect? Does it teach violence? Does it contribute to nihilism?'' Elsewhere he declaims, ''All that is clear is the perfection of what we were given, the unworthiness of our response, and the certainty, in view of our current deprivation, that we are judged.''
The severity of his own judgment is relieved to a degree by one of his recurring motifs: the image of a rural road stretching from the foreground to the distant horizon. ''Sally, Weld County, Colorado'' (1984) has in it something that, curiously, occurs rarely in his pictures: an animal. Specifically, it is a dog. It pauses on a dirt road perhaps 10 yards away, looking back over its shoulder as if to invite us to follow and to wonder: ''Where do we come from? What are we? Where are we going?'' The end, after all, remains for all of us to determine.
''Robert Adams: The Place We Live, a Retrospective Selection of Photographs'' continues through Oct. 28 at the Yale University Art Gallery, 1111 Chapel Street, New Haven; (203) 432-0600, artgallery.yale.edu.

HEADLINE: At Some Schools, the Demographic Future Is Now

BYLINE: By MORGAN SMITH. 
msmith@texastribune.org

 BODY:
Certain characteristics set the Laredo Independent School District apart from most other districts in the state.
Its western boundary aligns directly with the Mexican border. Nearly all its students are poor, and nearly all are Hispanic. Most rely on the school to provide two meals a day. On the first day of school this week, some showed up without shoes, or without parents accompanying them.
''It's hard to work on teaching them about reading and writing and math when they haven't eaten. It's hard to really welcome them into their class with their textbooks and their lockers when they don't have on shoes,'' said A. Marcus Nelson, the Laredo superintendent, who said the district solicited donations of shoes and dress-code-appropriate clothes all summer to prepare for the new school year. 
But geography aside, Texas public schools may increasingly find more in common with the South Texas district. In 2011, the state reached two landmarks. For the first time, Hispanics became the majority of public school students. And to cope with a historic budget deficit, the Legislature did not finance enrollment growth in the state's schools -- something that had not happened since the modernization of the Texas public school system in 1949. Though the first turning point passed quietly and the second with much political strife, they both underscore the challenges ahead as a dramatic demographic shift occurs in public school classrooms statewide.
By 2050, the number of Texas public school students is expected to swell to nine million from roughly five million now, and nearly two-thirds will be Hispanic, according to Steve Murdock, a demographer and director of Rice University's Hobby Center for the Study of Texas. The overall percentage of white students will drop by half to about 15 percent. Without an accompanying change in Hispanics' current socioeconomic status, that also means Texas students will continue to grow poorer -- and their education more expensive -- in the next four decades, Dr. Murdock added. (Rice University is a corporate sponsor of The Texas Tribune.)
State population figures over the last decade show the shift is well under way in the public school system. Economically disadvantaged children in Texas classrooms make up 60 percent of all public school students, up from less than half in 2000. Students with limited English skills now make up 16 percent of them. Of about 979,000 children added to the state's under-18 population from 2000 to 2010, 931,000 were Hispanic.
''When you look at children, there is no doubt. The future of Texas -- the future of the United States -- is tied to the minority population,'' said Dr. Murdock, a former state demographer and director of the United States Census Bureau. ''It's just mathematically true.''
If current trends hold, such projections make for a bleak forecast. According to state data, Hispanic students are statistically less likely to leave high school with a diploma than their white peers. Of the Hispanic students who do graduate, a minority are prepared for college. In 2010, 42 percent met college-readiness benchmarks in both English and math, compared with 66 percent of white students.
Among economically disadvantaged students and those with limited English proficiency, the gap continues to widen. Thirty-eight percent of students who came from low-income households did well enough on their Texas Assessment of Knowledge and Skills or college entrance exams to qualify as ''college ready.'' Only 5 percent of those with limited English language skills did so.
The Laredo district, along with a handful of others, including the Pharr-San Juan-Alamo district, near McAllen, has had a head start in educating the kinds of students who will make up more of the state's public schools. It has had successes -- graduation rates for both districts have consistently surpassed the state average for Hispanics -- but has also had to learn to embrace the additional challenges that come with serving students from at-risk backgrounds.
The methods that Dr. Nelson said Laredo uses to reach its students range from the simple, like having days where students wear their favorite college shirts to class, to the more complicated task of familiarizing teachers with the problems their students confront outside the classroom. That can mean starting out with the basics -- defining words like ''assessment'' and ''equation'' -- so that students know how they are being evaluated.
The district has also created a partnership with Texas A&M International University to create an early college high school in which students can take courses that allow them to graduate with college credits in hand. All of the efforts revolve around the goal of changing the expectations that students had for themselves, Dr. Nelson said.
Much of that, he said, is emphasizing that ''what you were born into does not have to be your lot in life, you are just going to have to dig down and really buy into our system of teaching and learning in the 21st century.''
''We've got kids that are poor, and we've got kids that are Hispanic, but we've also got kids that are some of the best and brightest kids in the state,'' Dr. Nelson said.
That is a shift in perspective that needs to happen in the way policy makers at the state and district level think about educating Hispanic and low-income students, said Patricia Lopez, a research associate at the University of Texas at Austin's Texas Center for Education Policy. (The University of Texas at Austin is a corporate sponsor of The Texas Tribune.)
Too often, Ms. Lopez said, students, rather than the institutions that serve them, are seen as the problem. ''We don't sit back and ask is the challenge really about the capacities of the schools and the people within those schools not being up to par,'' she said. ''We have not invested in that, so that those kids aren't coming into a context where failure is seen as a function of them.''
The state budget cuts in 2011, when lawmakers reduced public education financing by more than $5 billion, have exacerbated that, Ms. Lopez said. But the issue also needs to be addressed in teacher and principal recruitment programs, which she said could help make school leaders aware of their own biases in the classroom and better understand the world their students inhabit.
''It's more common to hear things like kids take poverty into schools, kids take broken home into schools,'' she said, ''but people who are educators also take their baggage into schools.''
If Texas can adequately educate the new student majority, Dr. Murdock said, the potential reward is large. As a state with a population that is, over all, growing younger rather than older, its work force would be competitively poised to replace a generation of retiring baby boomers, he said, taking advantage of the accompanying economic opportunity and higher incomes.
There has been some improvement. Over the last decade, the gap between the academic achievement of white and Hispanic students in the state has narrowed. But even if the gap continued to close at the current rate, it would still not be enough to ensure the state's success, Dr. Murdock said.
''It says I need to run fairly quickly from here to the finish line, or maybe I wont get to the finish line,'' he said.
Inside the Numbers: This article is part of an occasional series that uses data to investigate the trends inside Texas classrooms.

HEADLINE: A Suitor Makes the Case for Divorce

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG

 BODY:
TAMPA, Fla. -- Through three nights of gauzy videos, sentimental testimonials and, finally, his own address to the nation Thursday, Mitt Romney worked hard to show he has a heart.
But he still needs to tackle the much harder job of convincing those Americans who so emotionally invested their hearts in President Obama four years ago that it is time to accept that his presidency did not work, let go of him and move on.
Not even Mr. Romney's own strategists are pretending that is going to be simple. And even before leaving the nominating convention here, they were beginning a delicate 10-week campaign aimed at those voters who are disappointed in Mr. Obama but just can't yet bring themselves to quit him.
After month after month of disappointing job numbers, poll after poll showing dissatisfaction in his economic performance and hundreds of millions of dollars in negative advertisements, a large portion of wavering voters maintain a personal attachment to Mr. Obama, and a tentative willingness to give him more time to get it right, top strategists with both campaigns agree. 
That is a testament, perhaps, to the power of that scene four years ago when Mr. Obama and his family crossed the threshold of the White House as its first African-American tenants, ''an inspiring moment that so many have awaited so long'' as former President George W. Bush -- the man he was so hard on in 2008 -- put it then.
Representative Paul D. Ryan may have painted a biting picture on Wednesday night when he referred to the faded Obama poster hanging above unemployed college graduates' childhood beds, but the poster was still there, after all.
Most challengers face the relatively clinical task of persuading voters to fire the incumbent. Mr. Romney faces the more fraught mission of persuading them to break up with the incumbent.
''It's going to be hard to break the bond a lot of voters feel with Obama, even if they are disappointed,'' said Mark McKinnon, a former strategist for Mr. Bush. ''It may be a bad marriage, but they still want to save it.''
It is Mr. Romney's job now to convince them that it is beyond repair; that the risks of staying in it are larger than the risks of starting anew with him, that he and Mr. Ryan represent a fresh start akin to a generational change.
But leading these voters -- many of them women -- to that conclusion takes finesse and delicacy, Republican strategists say. The sort of visceral attacks that conservative talk show hosts are calling for risk sending them into a defense posture on behalf of Mr. Obama and, more to the point, of their own decisions four years ago.
Rather, strategists say, it requires providing a path that gives them permission to make a break. They need to be told that it is O.K. to remain proud of their initial support for Mr. Obama, but that they can be equally at peace with a decision to change their minds now.
''There is no need to make people feel bad about what they've done to feel good about what they're going to do,'' said Stuart Stevens, a senior adviser to Mr. Romney, as he sat in the empty convention hall Thursday afternoon in nervous anticipation of his boss's speech.
So it was that Mr. Romney went out of his way to tip his hat to the historic import of Mr. Obama's election, when he said ''many Americans felt a fresh excitement about the possibilities of a new president.''
But, in what amounted to perhaps the most forceful and effective portion of his address, Mr. Romney sought to give Mr. Obama's wavering 2008 voters a strong nudge from what he portrayed as a reverie, saying they have given the president time enough. ''Americans have been patient; Americans have supported this president in good faith,'' he said to a roar in the hall. ''Today the time has come to turn the page.''
The exhortation seemed aimed at disappointed swing voters, who, some polls show, might be inclined to give Mr. Obama more time because he inherited an economy in dire shape.
Mr. Romney's tone -- more lament than anger -- appeared to some analysts to be the most effective means of wresting away former Obama voters. ''There are signs he is making progress,'' Mr. McKinnon said, pointing to some polls that show Mr. Obama trailing Mr. Romney among independent voters.
This is not to say that there will be any going soft on Mr. Obama. Mr. Romney's campaign is running a raft of harsh advertisements against the president, including one that has been repeatedly criticized by news media ''fact checkers'' for falsely alleging he is stripping work requirements from the 1996 welfare overhaul law.
On Thursday Mr. Romney laced into Mr. Obama for bringing ''disappointment and division.'' And the evening before, Mr. Ryan gave something of a stemwinder, assailing Mr. Obama on multiple grounds, including running up the national debt.
With a newly flush bank account -- his acceptance of the nomination triggered the release of the money he collected for the general election -- Mr. Romney can afford to send out both harder-hitting and more nuanced messages at once for the first time since he emerged earlier this year as his party's presumed nominee.
And Mr. Ryan, 42, perhaps has a bit more leeway than Mr. Romney, 65, representing his own brand of change as the first vice-presidential nominee of Generation X, and his unveiling here has screamed ''new direction.'' Mr. Romney's aides have aggressively put him forward to make Mr. Obama look like the old order, turnabout for the man who took ownership of ''Change.''
And that goes to the other part of the equation here: Even if Mr. Romney's campaign continues to make inroads on the firing part, it has to make up ground on the hiring part, with polls showing him as lagging Mr. Obama on several personal ''likability'' measures.
''They see this guy as wealthy, disconnected, not like me,'' Margaret Spellings, Mr. Bush's former education secretary, said of wavering Obama voters during an interview here on Thursday. She said those voters were looking for ''the humanity side,'' of Mr. Romney, which his campaign did so much to present during this convention.
Ms. Spellings suggested that Mr. Romney had so far failed to overcome Mr. Obama decisively among undecided voters only because ''some of them haven't been paying attention.''
With some 20 million people tuning in on Wednesday night, according to Nielsen ratings, they are now. And they will have less than 10 weeks to decide whether Mr. Obama's ''hope and change'' will remain another faded poster on the wall or can become a frame-worthy heirloom with four more years.
